[The Forest of]545-the forest of [God]186-god ( Annotated Translation of [D.O. Fagunwa]187-fagunwa : Igbo Vlodumare ) by . [Gabriel A. Ajadi AGBO]188-gabriel ajadi AREO PUBLISHERS

This work , which was originally a Ph.D. dissertation submitted to [Ball State University]4-ball state university ; [Muncie]5-muncie , [Indiana]6-indiana , [USA]7-usa . is gratefully dedicated to [[my]0-i motiier]547-my motiier , [Estiier Olateium Ajadi]189-estiier olateium ajadi , [[my]0-i father]548-my father , [Jacob Afolabi Ajadi]190-jacob afolabi ajadi , [[my]0-i wife]549-my wife , [Caroline Omotanbaje Ajadi]191-caroline omotanbaje ajadi , [[my]0-i children]550-my children , [Qmobola]8-qmobola , [Oluwafunmilola]9-oluwafunmilola , [Oluwafunmike]10-oluwafunmike , [Ctyebisi]192-ctyebisi and [Stephen Babatunde Ajiboye Ajadi Jnr]193-stephen babatunde ajiboye ajadi jnr . , ' and , above all , to the glory of [God]186-god and [the Lord Jesus Christ]194-christ . iii ![193-stephen babatunde ajiboye ajadi jnr]

Acknowledgement [Thomas Nelson]195-thomas nelson & Sons ( Publishers , [United Kingdom]551-united kingdom and [Nigeria]11-nigeria ) are gratefully acknowledge for [their]552-their permission granted , to translate this work from its original Yoruba edition into English . IV

Preface Fa^wa is now coming into the limelight in the contemporary trend of African literary scholarship . The major attention given to [his]553-his works comes mainly from [the Yoruba scholars who are able to read and appreciate [Fagimwa]196-fagimwa 's artistic skills]554-the yoruba scholars who are able to read and appreciate fagimwa 's artistic skills . Only [a few non - native scholars]555-a few non - native scholars , like [Bemth Lirtdfors]197-bemth lirtdfors , [Ulli Beier]198-ulli beier , and [others]556-others , have been able to address memselves to some friematic or structural aspects of [his]553-his works and [they]555-a few non - native scholars are not unaided by either [the native speakers of [Yoruba]12-yoruba]557-the native speakers of yoruba or the limited translations tfiat are available to [them]555-a few non - native scholars . Thus interested foreign sciKJlars have been impeded by the linguistic barrier which [the native scholars]558-the native scholars have yet to remove completely ; hence a persistent demand . . feanslation of [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's works into Engli^. It is Ae purpose of this translation , therefore , to respond to such an urgent demand . Thus [I]0-i decided to set for [myself]0-i the task of translating ^d annotating [Fatwa]199-fatwa 's Olodiunaie , s. second volume of [his]553-his first novel , Ogboju Ode ninu Igbo Intnmole , which is already belated by [a Yoruba scholar]559-a yoruba scholar , [Wole Soyinka]200-wole soyinka , as [The Forest of A [Hunter]201-hunter]560-the forest of a hunter ['s Saga^ published in [London]14-london by [Nelson]195-thomas nelson]13-'s saga^ published in london by nelson in 19^. Both the philosophy and the method of translation employ^ in franslatiofi aregeared toward the achievement of an ^uivalent effecf and to the unveiling of the linguistic curtain in order that [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's meaning and spirit might come alive in [his]187-fagunwa own words arid style m the English edition . This way , the readership and toe schola^ip of [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's corpus may be widened , and toe Jjonzoi^ of the gmeral readers in English expanded . With this hope , this ^hon of [Olodumare]253-igbo olodumare as [The Forest of God]186-god is sent forth among [toe general readers]561-toe general readers and [toe scholars]562-toe scholars . Gabriel A. Ajadi D^artment of Modem European Languages [University of florin florin VJarflraiy]563-university of florin florin vjarflraiy 1994

Introduction D.O. [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's Igbo Olodumare { [The Forest of God]186-god ) , is a novel about the story of [Olowo - aiye]283-olowo - aiye 's adventure in [tine Forest of God]564-tine forest of god . [Olowo - aiye]283-olowo - aiye sets out to [Igbo Olodumare]341-god ( [The Forest of God)out]18-the forest of of sheer love for an adventure and [a guest]565-a guest for an opportunity to prove [himself]283-olowo - aiye as [a powerful hunter who can not be daunted by the awe of the unknown]566-a powerful hunter who can not be daunted by the awe of the unknown — a basic characteristic of [the traditional Yoruba hunter]567-the traditional yoruba hunter . Thus [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa , in [his]187-fagunwa characteristic vividness of imagination , artistic prowess , dazzling language , and a com pallin g ■ descriptive skill , prefects events and episodes around [Olowo - aiye]283-olowo - aiye as [he]187-fagunwa moves along onhis journey to , in , and from [Igbo Olodumare]341-god . The events and the episodes are those of [Olowo - aiye]283-olowo - aiye 's struggle with the trolls , gnomes , weird creatures ; and [his]187-fagunwa visits to the sage , ( [Mr ) Death]205-death , and [Miss Disease]206-disease . After this experience - packed sojourn in [the Forest of]545-the forest of [God]186-god , [ho]187-fagunwa finally returns [home]569-home , to join [[his]187-fagunwa family]570-his family , and to rejoice at the sight of [[his]187-fagunwa son]571-his son , [Akara - Ogun]207-akara - ogun , who is now grown . [Akara - ogun]207-akara - ogun , of course , is the hero of [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's first novel Ogboju Ode ninu Igbo Irunmgl^ translated by [Wole Soyinka]200-wole soyinka as [The Forest of [a Thousand Daemons]573-a thousand daemons]572-the forest of a thousand daemons ; [A Hunter]574-a hunter 's Saga . , This work translates and annotates [D.O. Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's Igbo Olodumarewiih a critical introduction which is divided into seven parts . Pa , rt one deals with file literature review , while part two deals with a brief biography of [D.O. Fagunwa]187-fagunwa , [the author]575-the author , whose Judeo - Christian background , [his]187-fagunwa culture , and . the tradition and the world - view of [[his]187-fagunwa ethnic group]576-his ethnic group — [Yoruba]202-yoruba shape [his]187-fagunwa thgught pattern and [his]187-fagunwa imagination . These cultural , traditiorial and philosophical backgrdund strongly Inform [his]187-fagunwa work of art . Part three briefly comments on file thought - pattern that informs [his]187-fagunwa works , emphasizes and explains the nature of [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's dichotomized world , a concept that emanates from [his]187-fagunwa cultural and traditional background . Part four gives a synopsis of [his]187-fagunwa ( [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's ) Igbo Olodumare wifii a brief comment on the structure and the symbolic aspects of the novel . Par t five briefly discusses the structure , syn^x and file tone of file language in which [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa wrote — [Yoruba]12-yoruba — a linguistic parameter which makes the attempt of translating Yoruba literature to English a difficult task . As a corollary to that part , part six discusses [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's ffietorical prowess as evident in [his]187-fagunwa esoteric use of Yoruba , a technique which saturates [his]187-fagunwa entire novels , and makes [him]187-fagunwa [fire master of [his]187-fagunwa mother tongue]577-fire master of his mother tongue . Thus it is [tihe translator]578-tihe translator 's task to adequately convey in English , a nontonal language , the rhythm and the verbal gymnastics Which [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa displays , particularly in [his]187-fagunwa Ig^o Olodumare ( [The Forest of God]186-god ) . The last part , part seven , spells [the translator]579-the translator 's main objective , philosophy , and the mefiiod of translation . The overriding objective , file note explains/ is readability , intelligibility and an equivalent effect . ' [Iri]208-iri order to achieve this end , file translation is annotated , while the idea of narrative bridge is ventured as ’[187-fagunwa] a mechanism which allows a smooth flow of filenarratives in the translated edition . [Furfiiermore]209-furfiiermore , [the translator]579-the translator 's stylistic idiosyncrasy is sacrificed in order to unveil [the author]575-the author 's meanings in [his]575-the author own words and style . ■ . . 1

Part I : Literature Review [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa is now attracting critical attention in contemporary African literary scholarship . The major attention given to [his]187-fagunwa works comes.mainly from [the Yoruba scholars who are able to read and appreciate [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's artistic skills]582-the yoruba scholars who are able to read and appreciate fagunwa 's artistic skills . Only a few nOTi - [native scholars]583-native scholars , like [Bemth Lindfofs]210-bemth lindfofs , [UHi Beier]198-ulli beier and [a few others]584-a few others have been able to address [themselves]583-native scholars to some thematic or structural aspects of [his]187-fagunwa works , and [they]583-native scholars are not unaided either by [the native speakers]585-the native speakers ' of [Yoruba]12-yoruba or the limited translations that are available to [them]583-native scholars . Thus interested [foreign scholars]4061-foreign scholars have been impeded by the linguistic barrier which [the native scholars]558-the native scholars have yet to remove complete^. When this is done , both the readership and the scholarship of [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's corpus shoidd be widened . Thus far , only two translations of the first short chapter of Igbo Olodiunare(The Forest ofGod)}\sve been done . One was by [A. A. Akinwowo]211-a. a. akinwowo , and the other jointly by both [Bakare Gbadamosi]212-bakare gbadamosi and [Ulli Beier.^ Wole Soyinka]200-wole soyinka , [[Africa]19-africa 's foremost novelist]4063-africa 's foremost novelist , [poet , playwright , actor and stage director]4064-poet , playwright , actor and stage director , has translated into English [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's first novel , Ogboju Ode ninu Igbolrunmgleas [The Forest of]18-the forest of [a Thousand Daemoi^s]4065-a thousand daemoi^s : [A Hunter]574-a hunter 's Sa^ , which was published by [Nelstm]21-nelstm in [London]14-london in 1968 . These limited translations are the cmly material with which [the non - Yoruba scholars]4067-the non - yoruba scholars can work . Therefore , there is an urgent need for more translations that '[198-ulli beier] would respect flie intention and fee spirit and the style of [the author]575-the author . In a way of critical analysis of [his]575-the author works , there have been articles addressing selected friemes in [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's works , but frid most definitive and comprehensive wcrk finis ' far is Ayo Bamgbose 's The Novels of D.O. [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa ) . [Benin City]23-benin city : Efiuope Publishing Corporation , 1973 . [Bamgbose]213-bamgbose aptly describes [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa as : ... [a pioneer in the field of creative writing in [Yoruba]12-yoruba]4068-a pioneer in the field of creative writing in yoruba . Before [him]187-fagunwa [no other writer]4069-no other writer has had the same impacton the Yoruba literary scene , nor file same influence on [subsequent Writers]4070-subsequent writers . The appearance of [his]187-fagunwa uavA , Ogbcyu Ode ninu Igbo Irunmole makes an imporfimt stage ip file development of Yoruba written language.^ [Bam^ose]214-bam^ose follows this thesis through in [his]214-bam^ose book by bringing out clearly vfiiat is traditional in terms of what is distinctively Yoruba in [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's works : '[575-the author] The setting of [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's novels , ' [he]214-bam^ose ma&itains , '[575-the author] is [Yoruba country]587-yoruba country and culture';^ this culture , of coyrse is not ' static '[575-the author] , but dynamic . * [He]575-the author identifies [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's sources as : ' ( a ) Yoruba folktales , ( b ) literary works in English including translations , which must have fonned part of fire background of [educated Nigerians of [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa]4071-educated nigerians of fagunwa 's time , and ( c ) Christian religious literature . '^[575-the author] Following the lead set by [L. Murby]215-l. murby in [[his]215-l. murby famous editor]588-his famous editor 's foreword to ( [he]215-l. murby 1950 edition of [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's O^oju Ode ninulgboIrunmole , [Bamgbose]213-bamgbose goes as far as identifying the dassictJ literature whidi constitutes another dimensian of effect to [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's literary ingredients , notably ' [Homer]216-homer 's Oc^ss^and Greek myths , '[213-bamgbose] as well as a ' minor influence ci [Aesop]217-aesop 's Fables/ and ( [he]215-l. murby ancient Arabian Nig^tsf '[213-bamgbose] Becarise of fiiese sources , [Bamgbose]213-bamgbose maintains fiiat [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's works are not original . However , [he]213-bamgbose maintains fiiat ' ( [he]187-fagunwa only aspect of file treatment of 2[213-bamgbose]

the material which is distinctively [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa is the w^y.he re - teUs the stories in [his]187-fagunwa own words , sometimes elaborating them by thd inclusion of dialogue . ' In this sense , [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's works fall in the category of what [TS]218-ts . [Eliot]219-eliot describes as originality : [Our]4072-we tendency to insist ; when [we]4072-we praise [a poet]4073-a poet , upon those aspects Of [his]4073-a poet work in which [he]4073-a poet least resembles any ohe else . fa these aspects or parts of [his]4073-a poet work [we]4072-we pretend to find whatiis - individual , what is the peculiar essence of [the man]4074-the man . [We]4072-we dwell with satisfaction upop [a poet]4073-a poet 's difference from [[his]4073-a poet predecessors]4076-his predecessors ; [we]4072-we endeavour to find somefiiing that can be isolated fa order to bp enjoyed . Whereas if [we]4072-we approach [a poet]4073-a poet -without this prejudice [we]4072-we shall find that not only the best , but the most individual parts of [his]4073-a poet work may be those in which [the dead poets]4078-the dead poets , [[his]4073-a poet ancestors]4079-his ancestors , assert [their]4079-his ancestors immortality more vigorously.^ Judged on this basis , [Fagunfwa]220-fagunfwa is most original even in the way [he]220-fagunfwa makes use of the material [he]220-fagunfwa imports fend employs in [his]220-fagunfwa works . [Bamgbose]213-bamgbose discusses the major themes and motifs of [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's novels . They include : '[213-bamgbose] perseverance , ' '[187-fagunwa] treachery ' , '[593-other scholars of fagtawa] retribution ' , '[589-women] [women]589-women ' '[593-other scholars of fagtawa] [man]590-man and other creatures ' and '[589-women] love ' [He]213-bamgbose does not forget [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's propensity to be didactic , thus [he]213-bamgbose devotes a whole chapter to tiiis . In the main , [Bamgbose]213-bamgbose 's book gives a surgical approach to the novels of [D.O. Fagunwa]187-fagunwa . In the last analysis , [he]213-bamgbose comments on [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's love for words , for '[591-his] in [his]591-his use of language , [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa shows an incredible feeling for words and their effects , ' ® and that is why , '[591-his] in spite of modem criticisms of [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's novels as ' mere fantasies , '[591-his] [many people]592-many people continue ^0 read them with delict . ' ’[593-other scholars of fagtawa] [Other scholars of [Fagtawa]221-fagtawa]593-other scholars of fagtawa 's ' works include [A. Olubumo]222-olubumo , who simply gives the synopsis of all the novels , and faults [him]187-fagunwa for '[593-other scholars of fagtawa] inability to create character ' and '[593-other scholars of fagtawa] improbability of plot>'^bpt conclude by saying that ' [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa may be described as a writer of atjj^ture stories which lire partly realistic and partly fantastic . '' ® *feowing [FagunWa]187-fagunwa and [[his]187-fagunwa audience]4080-his audience , [Olubumo]222-olubumo aptly says that [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's didacticism does not bother [[his]187-fagunwa audience]4080-his audience , for [they]4080-his audience even '[594-he] expect it . ' ” [Ulli Beier]198-ulli beier , [a German scholar]4082-a german scholar , faults [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa for [his]187-fagunwa '[594-he] plot is a rambling somewhat disorganized fairy tale . '^*- Critics fault [him]187-fagunwa for lack of realistic plot , but [they]4080-his audience should bear in mind that '[187-fagunwa] [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa does not attempt to solve any problems in [his]187-fagunwa books . [He]187-fagunwa has two simple aims as [a writer]595-a writer : [he]187-fagunwa tries to delict and to entertain : [he]187-fagunwa also tries , alas , to instruct and improve [[his]187-fagunwa reader]596-his reader . But [he]187-fagunwa succeeds so excellently well in [his]187-fagunwa first aim , that [we]597-we willingly forgive han file second . '^ ® [Abiola Irele]223-irele 's article is considered file most well - written and one of the most scholarly articles that have thus.far been written on [the three outstanding traditional writers]4083-the three outstanding traditional writers : [D.O. Fagunwa]187-fagunwa , [Amos Tutuola]224-tutuola , and [Wole]200-wole soyinka Soyin^. [He]223-irele provides an analysis of file drift in fte trend of literary creation in [Africa]19-africa ; thus [he]223-irele maintains that the essential direction of modem Afiican -writing , of the work of [the truly significant writers]4084-the truly significant writers , is towards the definition , in and through literature , of an imaginative apprehension and embodiment of an African spirit.^ ® 3[187-fagunwa]

While this is true of [other African writers]598-other african writers , in [no other area of [Africa]19-africa]599-no other area of africa is the current along which tfiis elaboration in literatureof a continuous stream of the collective consciousness from the traditional to the modem so clearly evident , and so well marked out , as ' in [Yorubaland]24-yorubaland Thus [these writers]4085-these writers , each in [his]600-his own unique way , expresses [his]600-his aesthetic vision through the artistic expression which emanates from a common stock of tradition : Yoruba mythology , cosmology and the collective apprehension of [the universe]4086-the universe . Thus coftceming [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's artistic recapitulation - and the interpretation of the tradition from which [his]600-his work evolves , [Irele]223-irele comments that : the significance of [his]600-his work is thus inherent in the symbolic framework ''[187-fagunwa] and connotations of [his]600-his novels . A simple but valid interpretation of tfie patten ) of situation in [his]600-his novels suggests that [[his]600-his forest]601-his forest stands for [the universe]4086-the universe , inhabited by obscure farces to which [man]590-man stands in a dynamic mqral and spiritual rdationship and with which [his]600-his destiny is involved ; in short , a mythical representation of the existential condition of [man]590-man as expressed in Yoruba thinking.^ ® With [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa begins an enduring literary tradition through which the content of the traditi^ and culture which shape [his]600-his work is artistically expressed . Therefore , [Tutuola]224-tutuola , though writing in English — the choice of language which had for a long time until recently clouded [his]224-tutuola literary achievement in [Nigeria]11-nigeria — follows in the literary traction of which [D. O. Fagunwa]187-fagunwa Is a forerunner , for ' it is cle^ that [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa ... provided not only the original inspiration but indeed a good measure of the material for [Tutuola]224-tutuola 's novel . The echo^ df [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa in [Tutuola]224-tutuola 's work are numerous enou^ to indicate that [the latter]4087-the latter was creating from a model provided by [the fermer]4088-the fermer . '^^[224-tutuola] [Tutuola]224-tutuola , however , lhaintains [his]224-tutuola distinctive identity through [his]224-tutuola ' visionary powers '[224-tutuola] , for ... Where [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa achieves a personal reorganisation of the traditional material , and is thus able to put [his]187-fagunwa stamp on this material in [his]187-fagunwa own writings — aided especially by the gift of [Imguage]226-imguage — one feels that with [Tutuola]224-tutuola , there is a total reliving of the coUe^ve myth within tire individual consciousness . [The artist]605-the artist is here at the very centre of [his]605-the artist material and of the experience that it communicates.^*^ In other words , while [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa distances [himself]187-fagunwa from the artistic articulation of tire common content of the tradition which underlies [their]606-their literary art , [Tutuola]224-tutuola enters and participates in the aesthetic expression of tire content of that same tradition which [Irele]223-irele labels as tire ' Collective mytir'.^^ While [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa and [Tutuola]224-tutuola are closer to what [Irele]223-irele calls the '[223-irele] well - springs of tire culture ' , [Wole Soyinka]200-wole soyinka 's work does not have such a direct connection , for '[223-irele] tire elements of tire traditional system are integrated into [tire writer]607-tire writer 's vision through tire mediation of a highly coirscious art'^ — highly conscious in tire sense that tire traditicmal elements have been filtered through a mind that is completely saturated with tire ncxr - African literary tradition . This is what [Irele]223-irele explains furtirer as [he]223-irele maintains , ' tiris means tirat in tire , case of [Soyinka]200-wole soyinka , the relationship of tire work to tire communal spirit passes titrough a process of personal rediscovery of traditional values and tire progressive approximation of tire individual artistic personality to tire determiiration of 4[223-irele]

? ( Jcollective consciousness . '^ In spite of [his]223-irele distinction , [the three writers]4089-the three writers are related , for [their]4089-the three writers art bears the emblems of the common Yoruba world - view and tradition . [Tutuola]224-tutuola is , considered '[223-irele] [the spiritual heir of [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa]608-the spiritual heir of fagunwa ' while [Soyinka]200-wole soyinka is recognized a s [the '[223-irele] spiritual brother of [Tutuola]224-tutuola]4090-the ' spiritual brother of tutuola ' . * [Tutuola]224-tutuola , as [we]4091-we have already , seen , is quite close to [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa in that [Tutuola]224-tutuola echoes [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa in very many ways , but [Soyinka]200-wole soyinka maintains [his]200-wole soyinka individuality very strongly , with the exception of [his]200-wole soyinka : A Dance in [the Forest]4092-the forest , where the symbolic setting of the dramatic action is the same as in [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's novels , and where the figure of [the '[223-irele] half - child ']4093-the ' half - child ' may have been taken over from [Tutuola]224-tutuola 's Palm Wine [Diinkard]25-diinkard . ’[223-irele] Distinctively , therefore , what Sets [Soyinka]200-wole soyinka apart from [the other two writers]609-the other two writers , [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa and [Tutuola]224-tutuola , ' proceeds from a developed awareness of the multiple meanings that [his]200-wole soyinka art achieves . There is not only an intuitive participation of [the artist]605-the artist in [his]200-wole soyinka own symbols,-but an intellectual direction given to [them]609-the other two writers , as a means of an integrated and conscious artistic statement . '^[224-tutuola] ' * In a clear but complex fashion , [Irele]223-irele is able to sustain [his]223-irele theses that - the artistic experience of [the three writers , taken together]4095-the three writers , taken together , represents a development of die common stock of images in a way that is not only a restatement of their significance in the context of the traditional experience , but also of [their]4095-the three writers , taken together continuing truth for [modem man]4096-modem man . [Their]4095-the three writers , taken together work expresses the essence of myth as a comprehensive metaphor of life : as a reformulation of experience at the level of image and symbol so as to endow it with an intense spiritual significance . " In the last analysis , [Irele]223-irele 's article unveils the significance of [these writers]4085-these writers as eloquent articulators of the African mode pf thought and sensibility ; that [they]4095-the three writers , taken together stand as the '[227-olabimtan^] embodiment of [an African spirit]610-an african spirit ' and [their]4095-the three writers , taken together work becomes a pointer to [the Africans]4098-the africans '[231-olabimtan] mode of apprehension of reality . [Olabimtan^]227-olabimtan^ ® helps [us]611-us to see why religion^ themes permeate [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's novels : ' [he]227-olabimtan^ shows , through [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's family history that [[his]187-fagunwa father]4099-his father ( who later became [Joshua]228-joshua ) was formerly known as [Asungaga Beyioku]229-asungaga beyioku when [he]227-olabimtan^ .was [an Ifa priest]4100-an ifa priest , but after [his]227-olabimtan^ conversion , [he]227-olabimtan^ became [the baba ijo]4101-the baba ijo ( '[227-olabimtan^] Father of [the Congregation]612-the congregation ' ) of [[St. Luke]230-st. luke 's Church]26-st. luke 's church , [Oke Igbo]28-oke - igbo . '^[231-olabimtan] ® [Olabimtan]231-olabimtan argues that ' in the traditional Yoruba society the conviction that religion is a serious concern is one of the greatest forces . Every activity is linked with religion . Morality and religion are inseparable , and the great part of [children]4102-children 's education is rooted in religious observances . '^^[231-olabimtan] Thus [we]611-us are able to understand the basis of [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's excessive moralization and [his]187-fagunwa cohstant allusion to the Bible . With a meticulous search for religious ideas , [Olabimtan]231-olabimtan is able to identify the aspects of Yoruba traditional religion in [the hovels of [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa]613-the hovels of fagunwa . These examples are too numerous to be listed here . It is sufficient to point out that [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa , coming out of [his]187-fagunwa religious milieu , demonstrates in ids works of art that [God]186-god is [the God of all creations]614-the god of all creations , and that ' [he]187-fagunwa takes [God]186-god as the central , all governing source and measure of morality . Part II : [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa : A Brief Biography [Daniel Orowole Fagunwa]232-daniel orowole fagunwa was bom in [Oke - Igbo]28-oke - igbo in [what wad then [Western Nigeria]29-western nigeria]615-what wad then western nigeria , in the year 1903?^ [[His]187-fagunwa parents]616-his parents , [Joshua Akintunde]228-joshua and [Rachael Osunyomi]233-rachael osunyomi , were [converts to [the Judeo - Christian religian]618-the judeo - christian religian]617-converts to the judeo - christian religian . Therefore , it is not amiss to postulate the idea that [he]187-fagunwa became [a Christian]619-a christian too , as a result of both parental influence and the missionary impact on [his]187-fagunwa life . [His]187-fagunwa conversion , no doubt , led [him]187-fagunwa to reject [his]187-fagunwa middle name [Orowole]232-daniel orowole fagunwa which means ' Oro enters houM'.32 [He]187-fagunwa thus assumed the name [Olorunfemi]234-fagunwa { [God]186-god loves [me]232-daniel orowole fagunwa ) ’[232-daniel orowole fagunwa] as a substitute . [Fagunwa]234-fagunwa attended [[St. Luke]230-st. luke 's Day School at [Ok^Igbo]30-ok^igbo]620-st. luke 's day school at ok^igbo , [[his]234-fagunwa [home town]622-home town]621-his home town , from 1916 to 1924 . After [his]234-fagunwa elemental education , [he]234-fagunwa became [a pupil teacher]623-a pupil teacher in [the same school]624-the same school in the following year ( 1924 ) . [His]234-fagunwa teaching career as [an ' untrained pupil teacher]4103-an ' untrained pupil teacher '[4103-an ' untrained pupil teacher] lasted only for a year . In 1926 , [he]234-fagunwa entered [the then famous St. [Andrew]235-andrew 's College , [Oyo]31-oyo]625-the then famous st. andrew 's college , oyo . [He]234-fagunwa was tjhere for flwee years ( 1926 - 29 ) . After [his]234-fagunwa training , [he]234-fagunwa was posted to be in charge of [the Nursery Section of [the same St. Andrew 's Practising School]627-the same st. andrew 's practising school]626-the nursery section of the same st. andrew 's practising school . [He]234-fagunwa served in this capacity for nine years ( from 1930 - 1939 ) . [Fagunwa]234-fagunwa met [[his]234-fagunwa wife]628-his wife at [Modakeke]32-modakeke in the year 1931 . After a romantic courtship during which letters were reciprocated for about six years , [they]629-they were married in 1937 . Thus [Rebecca]236-rebecca became [[Daniel Olorunfemi Fagunwa]234-fagunwa 's companion]630-daniel olorunfemi fagunwa 's companion until [they]629-they were parted by death in 1963 . [[Fagunwa]234-fagunwa 's father]631-fagunwa 's father died in 1939 , an experience which [he]234-fagunwa skilfully weaves into the fabric of [his]234-fagunwa narrative in [his]234-fagunwa Igbo Olodumare : emi rqra joko ni temi , ti mo nwo cqu aiye , ti mo nxonu nipa awon omo enia , nitoii oniruru enia ni motiba gbe po ri . Akoko ighati mo nsqto yi , akoko pataki ni o je ni igbesi aiye mi , [niton igbana ni baba mi pa oju de , ti o rekoja oke cxlo]632-niton igbana ni baba mi pa oju de , ti o rekoja oke cxlo , ti o [I]0-i d aiye pe o digbose , ti akuko ko lehin cdcunrin ( p.2 ) . meaning : Thus was [I]0-i , sitting down quietly , looking at the eyes of life and musing about [the children of [men]634-men]633-the children of men , for [I]0-i have lived with [various kinds d people]635-various kinds d people . The time to which [I]0-i am now referring was a crucial period in [my]0-i life , for it was at that time that [[my]0-i father]548-my father shut [his]548-my father eyes , crossed to [[flte]33-flte other side of [rite river]638-rite river]637-flte other side of rite river , and bade [the world]639-the world gcxxlbye , and [the cock crew]640-the cock crew in [his]548-my father absence . It was shortly after [[his]0-i father]4099-his father 's death [ftrat Fagunwa]234-fagunwa was transferred from [Oyo]31-oyo to [Owo]34-owo to continue [his]234-fagunwa teaching career in [St. Patrick 's School]35-st. patrick 's school . [He]234-fagunwa tau^t [there]642-there from 1940 to 1942 . Between 1943 and 1946 , [he]234-fagunwa moved from [one school]643-one school to the other : [CMS Grammar School [Lagos]36-lagos]644-cms grammar school lagos , in 1943 ; in 1944 , [he]234-fagunwa taugjtf A * ® [[Giris]37-giris ' School in [Benin]39-benin]38-giris ' school in benin , and was at [Igbobi College]40-igbobi college , [Lagos]36-lagos ( when [Igbobi]237-igbobi was at [Ibadan]3-ibadan because of the ongoing World War H , before [flte school]4104-flte school was moved back to [Lagos]36-lagos in 1946 ) from 1W5 - 1956 . [Fagunwa]234-fagunwa won a British Council scholarship , and left [Nigeria]11-nigeria for [Britain]41-britain in 1946 . On [his]234-fagunwa return from [London]14-london in 1948 , [he]234-fagunwa was assigned to teach at [the Government Teacher Training Centre in [Ibadan]3-ibadan]42-the government teacher training centre in ibadan ; from 1948 to 1950 . In 1950 , 6[234-fagunwa]

[he]234-fagunwa went back to [Britain]41-britain to study , but [he]234-fagunwa was not able to complete [his]234-fagunwa degree course before [he]234-fagunwa was invited back to [tlje country]645-tlje country to become [an Education Officer]646-an education officer in 1955 . [He]234-fagunwa held this position ( the position which was in the area of the publications ) for four years , 1955 - 1969 . At the time , [he]234-fagunwa had bron noted as [a literary figure who was interested in [his]234-fagunwa mother]647-a literary figure who was interested in his mother tongue , [Yoruba]202-yoruba , so much that [he]234-fagunwa employed it in a ' graver subject '[234-fagunwa] like [Milton]238-milton . [He]234-fagunwa had published [his]234-fagunwa Ogboiu Odenintt Igbo InmmgleyA 1939 , and [his]234-fagunwa [Igbo Olodumare]341-god in 1946 , and [tney]239-tney Were both Reprinted in 1949 and 1950 respectively . ' -Fagunwa 's literary skill won [him]234-fagunwa the Margaret Wrong Prize in 1955 and a chieftancy title wHch was conferred on [him]234-fagunwa at [[his]234-fagunwa home town]621-his home town , [Oke - Igbo]28-oke - igbo , in 1956 . Three yearsTater , [he]234-fagunwa was awarded an M.B.E. title in 1959 . Before [his]234-fagunwa death , [he]234-fagunwa had been Working with [the Heinemann Educational Books Ltd]43-the heinemann educational books ltd as [a Representative in [Nigeria]11-nigeria]4106-a representative in nigeria . [He]234-fagunwa had travelled to [the Northern Nigeria]4107-the northern nigeria to collect some material for [his]234-fagunwa novel Which [he]234-fagunwa was writing , as was rumoured around , when , on [his]234-fagunwa way back , [he]234-fagunwa fell into [the River]4108-the river . [Niger]44-niger at [Baro]45-baro , as [he]234-fagunwa was waiting to be ferried across [the river]4108-the river , and was drowned on 7th December 1963 . 7[234-fagunwa]

Part III : [Fagunwa^s Works D.O. Fagunwa]187-fagunwa was [a respected educator]648-a respected educator who stood for the best in terms of training [the younger generation]649-the younger generation , uplifting and disseminating the ideals of [[his]648-a respected educator country]650-his country and [[his]648-a respected educator Yoruba culture]651-his yoruba culture . [He]648-a respected educator saw literary art as the best means thrdugh which [he]648-a respected educator could insulate the values of the cultural heritage of [the Yoruba people]652-the yoruba people upon [the younger generation]649-the younger generation specifically , and of making the tradition and the culture known to all " [the people]654-the people ? who ( either through the rendering of [his]648-a respected educator works into English and others tongues^ ® or by any othw means such as movies) ® '^ might come in contact with [his]648-a respected educator novels , thereby sharing the wealth of [his]648-a respected educator imagination and literary craftsmanship . [He]648-a respected educator first demonstrated [his]648-a respected educator versatility , remarkable genius and productivity when [he]648-a respected educator wrote [his]648-a respected educator first novel for a creative writing contest , the contest which [he]648-a respected educator won creditably , as [Bamgbose]213-bamgbose notes that [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's first novel Ogboju Ode ninu Igbo Inmmole was written for a competition organized by [Miss Plumber]240-miss plumber in 1936 . [The Church Missionary Society]4110-the church missionary society bought the manuscript for £ 20 ( twenty pounds sterling ) and published it in 1938 . The book was an instant success , and was very ■ popular especially in [the schools]4111-the schools . ® ® The above excerpt about the history of [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's [Ogboju Ode Ninu Igbo Iruninole]241-ogboju ode ninu igbo iruninole is another due , apart from the moralistic nature of the Yoruba folklore , to [his]648-a respected educator propensity to overload [his]648-a respected educator narratives with excessive -didacticism , a trait for which [he]648-a respected educator is faulted by [some of [[his]648-a respected educator critics]4113-his critics]4112-some of his critics . ® ® Within a very short time in [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's literary career , [he]187-fagunwa had five major novels and other publications to [his]187-fagunwa credit . [His]187-fagunwa five major novels indude : [Ogboju Ode ninu IgJ]46-ogboju ode ninu igj > o [Irunmgle Nelson]242-nelson , 1950 ( first published by the CMS Bookshop , [Lagos]36-lagos , 1938 ) ; Jgbo Olodumare , [Edinburg]47-edinburg : [Nelson]242-nelson , 194^ Ireke Onibudc^ [Edinburgh]49-edinburgh : [I^elson]50-i^elson , 1954 ; Adiitu Olodunuue , [Edinburg]47-edinburg : [Nelson]242-nelson 1961 ; [Irinkerindo ninu Igbo Elegbeje]243-irinkerindo ninu igbo elegbeje , [Edinburg]47-edinburg : [Nelson]242-nelson , 1964 . The significance of [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's work lies not only in [his]187-fagunwa literary prowess and [his]187-fagunwa vividness of imagination alone , but in [his]187-fagunwa basic thought pattern , the thought pattern which is immersed in the tradition and culture of [[his]187-fagunwa Yoruba ethnic group]4114-his yoruba ethnic group . It is in this philosophical dimension that [he]187-fagunwa is able to transcend the limitation of [his]187-fagunwa culture"and [his]187-fagunwa traditional heritage , in order to universalize the scope of [his]187-fagunwa aesthetics . Therefore , it is not amiss to briefly examine this fiiou^t pattern in order to determine the way [he]187-fagunwa uses it to transcend [his]187-fagunwa culttue . Whatever imported material [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa Weaves into the total fabric of [his]187-fagunwa narratives ( for according to [Bamgbose]213-bamgbose 's clo?e analyses of [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's novels , [he]187-fagunwa draws from three major sources : '[187-fagunwa] Classical Greek Literature , English Literature , and the Arabian Nights') ® ^ [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's thought pattern is ’’ grounded in [his]187-fagunwa own world - view , the world - view which is also informed by [his]187-fagunwa culture and tradition . To [him]187-fagunwa , the nature of reality is not limited to the ’[187-fagunwa] objective perception of what is real alone , but it extends to that which is subjective as well . Therefore , [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's world is dichotomized : there is a world in which [we]655-we live and move , and there is [a world which [we]655-we can not see]656-a world which we can not see . [The former world]657-the former world is [the world of]658-the world of [man]590-man , and the latter is the world of'the spirits . 8

sznomes , [trolls]660-trolls , [fairies]661-fairies , ghosts , ghommids and kobolds [These beings]662-these beings are perceived as being in competition with [man]590-man ; [they]662-these beings claim to be superior to [m^ Ld man]244-m^ ld man in turn tries to claim [his]244-m^ ld man primary place in the umv«se ; [man]590-man is the apex of [God]186-god 's cieaticm ; the most superior who is the head of all the coated bSias . The claim by [the inhabitants of [both worlds]666-both worlds]665-the inhabitants of both worlds is the cause of the tension fhat^sts between'tiie two worlds , for [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa believes that [the invisible world]667-the invisible world is as real as [the visible world]668-the visible world . ... . ■ i u,;-This is basicaUy Yoruba cosmology , and it is interesting to note that this concept is in consonance with the world - view of [the early Chnsti^ u^e third Ltury of the Christian era]669-the early chnsti^ u^e third ltury of the christian era . It is also in line a. brand ! of psychology known as transpersonal^psydiology . not open - h^dedly accepted in [Western world]678-western world , especially in [the United Statesdt]51-the united statesdt is a valid , but non - objective truth . Its import is s^tomic^ : it is closely related to the brain structure , i.e. left and right henuspheres of theLhrain . Transpersonal psychology holds ttiat [man]590-man is mew than what biological arid physiological sciences can verify about [him]681-he . [he]681-he 9[245-howev]

extends beyond [himself]681-he , and , [he]681-he can perceive a world other than that which is open to [him]681-he . superior to [man]590-man . [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa , of course , never allows [man]590-man to be submerged or relegated to the background ; in order to prove that [man]590-man is truly the head of [tod 's created beings]723-tod 's created beings , [he]187-fagunwa allows poetic justice to take its course . It is an act of theistic affirmation in [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's narratives to allow that to happen , as [Lindfors]255-lindfors aptly observes : [The Christian God]724-the christian god even enters into the narrativjes occasionally as [an active agent of change]725-an active agent of change , [an omnipotent force that rescues [the righteous]727-the righteous and punishes [the wicked]728-the wicked]726-an omnipotent force that rescues the righteous and punishes the wicked . [A sinner]729-a sinner in [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's works is apt to die uttering a confession and declaration of useful remorse , ' Ah , is this how miserably [I]729-a sinner end ! '[729-a sinner] " Thus [Olowo - aiye]283-olowo - aiye overcomes [the troll]730-the troll eventually , a victory for [man]590-man and a vindication of [his]590-man superiority . Another encounter with [the inhabitant of [the unseen world]716-the unseen world]732-the inhabitant of the unseen world is [Olowo - aiye]283-olowo - aiye 's encounter with [Anjonnu - iberu]256-anjonnu - iberu who is [the gate - keeper of [Igbo Olodumare]341-god]734-the gate - keeper of igbo olodumare . [Olowo - aiye]283-olowo - aiye refuses to swear by the book in which all the sins of [men]634-men are listed . Again , after a long time of verbal altercation and fierce fighting with [the troll]730-the troll , [he]283-olowo - aiye overcomes hiirt , and a monument is built for [Olowo - aiye]283-olowo - aiye in [that forest]737-that forest with an inscription which immortalizes [his]283-olowo - aiye name and celebrates [his]283-olowo - aiye fortitude , thereby confirming [man]590-man as the head and the controller- of [the created beings]739-the created beings in both worlds.^ This kind of cosmology is in consonance with the basic world - view of [the Yoruba people]652-the yoruba people , as [Bamgbose]213-bamgbose aptly asserts : The numerous spirits , [trolls]660-trolls , [fairies]661-fairies arid gnomes that [the hero of Ogboju fights]743-the hero of ogboju fights do not belong entirely to the world of fiction . [The Yoruba]202-yoruba believe in the existence of [spirits of different forms]744-spirits of different forms not visible to [humans]745-humans but which nevertheless play an important part in [their]652-the yoruba people lives . It is obvious then that [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's thought pattern is not without a basis : it is deeply rooted in [his]187-fagunwa culture and tradition . [His]187-fagunwa imagination and literary vision emanate from [his]187-fagunwa philosophical milieu , for as [Owotnoyela]257-owotnoyela appropriately remarks : ' [he]187-fagunwa cultivated an intimate knowledge of the strange world of Yoruba mythology and its extraordinary inhabitants . '^[257-owotnoyela] In essence , theref ore , [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's use of weird creatures and [strange beings]746-strange beings and [his]187-fagunwa creation of an invisible realm of existence through the metaphor of [the forest]4092-the forest constitutes the truth qf fiction^ which permeates [his]187-fagunwa works . The fact that [his]187-fagunwa setting , [the forest]4092-the forest , is a metaphorical , archetypal and symbolic element of [his]187-fagunwa works is reinforced in [his]187-fagunwa epilogue to [his]187-fagunwa Igbo Olodumare ( [The Forest of]545-the forest of [God]186-god ) as [he]187-fagunwa warns [[his]187-fagunwa reader]596-his reader : E mase gbagbe wipe bi aiye ti dun to bena ni isoro inu re po to . back from [[his]751-his own Forest of [God]186-god]4135-his own forest of god without being wounded . Part IV : Igbo Olodumare ( [The Forest of [God]186-god]186-god ) A brief analysis of ? [agunwa]259-agunwa 's basic thought pattern as a thread that is wove ' into the total fabric of [his]187-fagunwa works leaves [us]4139-us with little to be said in terms of the background of this major , and perhaps the best of [his]187-fagunwa works , Igbo Olodumare ( [The Forest of [God]186-god]186-god ) , except to note the fact that the basic ingredients of [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's novels come from folk - tales , Yoruba mythology , and the foreign material as adumbrated by [Bamgbose]213-bamgbose who argues for and also substantiates the fact that [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa uses material from English literature , for [he]213-bamgbose believes that '[186-god] literary works in English , including translations , must have formed part of the background of [educated Nigerians of .Fagunwa]756-educated nigerians of .fagunwa 's time , and Christian literature . '^ , Igbo Olodumare ( [The Forest of God]689-the forest of god ) is the story of [Olowo - aiye]283-olowo - aiye , [the father of [Akara - ogun]207-akara - ogun , who is the main character of [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's first novel Ogboju Ode]4141-the father of akara - ogun , who is the main character of fagunwa 's first novel ogboju ode . [Olowo - aiye]283-olowo - aiye sets out to [Igbo Olodumare]253-igbo olodumare out of love for adventure and quest for an opportunity to prove [himself]283-olowo - aiye as [a powerful hunter who can not be daunted by the awe of the unknown]566-a powerful hunter who can not be daunted by the awe of the unknown , a basic characteristic of [the traditional Yoruba hunters]4143-the traditional yoruba hunters . Thus [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa , in [his]187-fagunwa characteristic vividness of imagination , artistic prowess , dazzling language and compelling descriptive skill , projects events and epis ’[259-agunwa] odes around [Olowo - aiye]283-olowo - aiye as [he]283-olowo - aiye moves along on [his]283-olowo - aiye journey to [Igbo Olodumare]341-god ( [The Forest of God]689-the forest of god ) , [he]283-olowo - aiye fights and overcomes [Esu - kekere - ode]248-esu - kekere - ode , courts [Ajediran]260-ajediran , gets into seemingly endless fight with [the troll]730-the troll , Anjonnu - iberu [the gate - keeper of [Igbo Olodumare]253-igbo olodumare]734-the gate - keeper of igbo olodumare , seducing and killing [him]283-olowo - aiye ; [he]283-olowo - aiye gains an entrance into [Igbo Olodumare]341-god without swearing by [his]283-olowo - aiye book.- [He]283-olowo - aiye wins the love and admiration of [the king]760-the king and [the citizens of [Igbo Olodumare]341-god]761-the citizens of igbo olodumare , and ends up this episode with a colorful wedding ; [the king]760-the king is delighted in joining [him]283-olowo - aiye and [[his]760-the king fiancee]763-his fiancee [Ajediran]260-ajediran in a delightful matrimony . From this point , [the narrator]4122-the narrator changes : [Akara - ogun]207-akara - ogun , up till this point , has been telling the story of [[his]207-akara - ogun father]4099-his father , [Olowo - aiye]283-olowo - aiye ; [he]207-akara - ogun now lets [Olowo - aiye]283-olowo - aiye tell [his]283-olowo - aiye own story through [his]283-olowo - aiye autobiography which [Akara - ogun]207-akara - ogun reads , as [the scribe]766-the scribe , presumably [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa [himself]187-fagunwa , writes down the story as a message to [the children of [the world]639-the world]767-the children of the world , a rationale for , and a method by which [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa sermonizes and moralizes with ease and delight . [Olowo - aiye]283-olowo - aiye goes out to hunt , but finds [himself]283-olowo - aiye in all kinds of predicaments , and gets stranded in [the forest]4092-the forest ; [he]283-olowo - aiye eventually finds [himself]283-olowo - aiye in [[the sage]770-the sage 's house]771-the sage 's house . [There]642-there , [[his]283-olowo - aiye host]773-his host , [Baba - onirugbon - yeuke]261-baba - qnirungbon - yeuke , introduces [him]283-olowo - aiye to [Mr. Death]205-death and [Ms. Disease]206-disease . [Ibanuje - isale]267-ibanuje - isale strays away as [the pilgrims]782-the pilgrims discovered , after leaving [the territory of [the seven vicious - headed women]784-the seven vicious - headed women]783-the territory of the seven vicious - headed women . A letter comes from [Baba - onirugbqn - yeuke]261-baba - qnirungbon - yeuke , the 13

l , etter to which [Olowo - aiye]283-olowo - aiye replies . [Olowo - aiye]283-olowo - aiye finds out that [[his]283-olowo - aiye wife]628-his wife has been taken [home]569-home . [He]283-olowo - aiye gets back [home]569-home and finds out that [[his]283-olowo - aiye son]571-his son , [Akara - ogun]207-akara - ogun , is grown . [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's artistic skill helps [him]187-fagunwa to structure the novel in a way that allows [him]187-fagunwa to moralize ; [his]187-fagunwa old friend'tells the story of [[his]187-fagunwa father]4099-his father , and the story is supposed to be an allegorical Inessage to [the children of [the world]639-the world]767-the children of the world . In the middle of the story , [the narrator]4122-the narrator changes ; [Olowo - aiye]283-olowo - aiye now tells [his]283-olowo - aiye own story , a story which is heavily laden with didacticism , and sermonettes . Through [his]187-fagunwa epilogue , however , [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa makes [his]187-fagunwa intention known : [he]187-fagunwa is out to teach , and [he]187-fagunwa does so very delightfully too . Thus didacticisrrf is not an accidental residue of [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's ’ naivete '[187-fagunwa] but a deliberate objective which [he]187-fagunwa achieves through the use of esoteric literary language , a compelling imagination , vivid imagery and an elevated rhetoric . The novel is basically cultural and traditional . [The characters]797-the characters , [weird or riormal]798-weird or riormal , walk , talk , eat , live and do things as [Yoruba people]799-yoruba people would . [They]797-the characters think like [the Yoruba]202-yoruba ; thus [their]797-the characters basic institutions such as kingship , and marriage are ' very Yoruba '[269-irelt] in nature Through the metaphor of the setting , [the forest]4092-the forest and the thought pattern as previously discussed , hdwever , [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa transcends the limitation of [his]187-fagunwa tradition and culture to universalize [his]187-fagunwa artistic prowess . Thus in essence , [Irelt]269-irelt 's insightful comment about [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's novels is basically true : ... [he]187-fagunwa strove , even with noticeable strain , to get beyond the limitations of tradition in the context of an extended literary medium.^ In this sense , [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa is not . [a writer who is limitpd to [his]187-fagunwa milieu]801-a writer who is limitpd to his milieu , but [J^e]270-j^e touches [all peoples]802-all peoples in all places by actively extending [himself]187-fagunwa through [his]187-fagunwa craftmanship . 14

PartV : [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's Language : [Yoruba Fagunwa]271-fagunwa , in spite of [his]187-fagunwa proficiency in English , determined , like [Milton]238-milton , about three and a half centuries before [him]187-fagunwa , to employ [his]187-fagunwa mother tongue ' in a graver subject '[213-bamgbose] > 5 Although as [Bamgbose]213-bamgbose reminds [us]803-us , in the mid-1930s when [Eagunwa]272-eagunwa began'his attempt at writing a novel , ' there was hardly any written tradition in [Yoruba]12-yoruba to fall back upon,'5 ° there was concerted effort by [the Chris tian missionaries]4144-the chris tian missionaries to encourage production of Christian literature in the vernacular of [the people among whom [they]4144-the chris tian missionaries laboured]4145-the people among whom they laboured . This , of course , was a fuellin g of the fire that was kindled by [Samuel Ajayi Crowther]273-samuel ajayi crowther , [one of [the freed slaves]4147-the freed slaves]4146-one of the freed slaves , [a Yoruba , who was baptized , and who was also one of the first graduates of [Fourah Bay College]55-fourah bay college which was founded in 1827 [He]273-samuel ajayi crowther was sent to [Nigeria]11-nigeria as [a CMS missionary]4149-a cms missionary to work among [[his]273-samuel ajayi crowther own people]4150-his own people]4148-a yoruba , who was baptized , and who was also one of the first graduates of fourah bay college which was founded in 1827 he was sent to nigeria as a cms missionary to work among his own people , [the Yoruba people]652-the yoruba people , in 1843.^^ One of the monumental achievements , pf [Bishop Ajayi Crowther]274-bishop ajayi crowther was [his]274-bishop ajayi crowther translation of the Bible into [Yoruba]12-yoruba as [Biheli]275-biheli 1900 . This was die genesis of die use of Yoruba language in some serious literary works , for [P.E.H. Hair]276-p.e.h. hair , as quoted by [Gerard]277-gerard , believes that that translation was of a literary order comparable with that of [Luther]278-luther 's German translation or die English Authorized Version '[274-bishop ajayi crowther] and that [Crowther]274-bishop ajayi crowther 's ' influence on subsequent literature ... without doubt was overwhelming for [his]274-bishop ajayi crowther choice of a dialect and [his]274-bishop ajayi crowther selection of idioms and expressions in thisdialect sanctified for [Yoruba reader]4152-yoruba reader through [his]274-bishop ajayi crowther Bible translations and for [the linguist]4153-the linguist through [his]274-bishop ajayi crowther grammar and dictionary , created Yoruba , which has now even affected the spoken language < md become so widespread that other dialects are rapidly disappearing . '^[274-bishop ajayi crowther] This gave rise to the subsequent varied literary works from the middle of the nineteenth century up till the late 1920s ; in the early 1930s those appeared as serialized story entitled Itan Igbesi Aiye Emi , Se^gga by [Isaac B. Thomas]279-isaac b. thomas who was then [the editor of the weekly'joumal known as [Akede Eko]280-akede eko]804-the editor of the weekly'joumal known as akede eko . ■ This story followed the tradition of the epistolary novel patterned after [Richardsdn]281-richardsdn 's Pame7a.5 ® With fine appearance bf [Fagunwa]271-fagunwa 's -first novel published by CMS . Bookshop , an epoch of a serious Yoruba literary tradition began . Yoruba language is spoken by about [12Vi million of [the 90 million to 100 million people in [Nigeria]11-nigeria]806-the 90 million to 100 million people in nigeria]805-12vi million of the 90 million to 100 million people in nigeria . [The speakers]807-the speakers are located in [the south - western part of [Nigeria]11-nigeria]808-the south - western part of nigeria , [the immediate northern part of [Nigeria]11-nigeria]809-the immediate northern part of nigeria — [Kwara State]56-kwara state — and [the eastern part of [Benin Republic]57-benin republic]810-the eastern part of benin republic . [Its]811-its origin is said to be Sudanic,= " but recent linguistic scholarship classifies [it]811-its as the member of [the Kwa branch of the Niger Kordofanian language family]812-the kwa branch of the niger kordofanian language family , 5 ® a notion which is not readily accepted by [most Yoruba linguists]813-most yoruba linguists . [Adetugbo]282-adetugbo , for example , discredits this idea on the basis of the fact that [scholars]814-scholars are not in agreement as to the origin of [all the people who speak the languages within [file Kwa family]816-file kwa family]815-all the people who speak the languages within file kwa family , for . It will be ... futile to isolate one of [the 600 or so group]817-the 600 or so group and posit for it an origin without reference to the history of [the other groups]818-the other groups . ' ® ’[816-file kwa family] Obviously , the argument about the origin of the language and of [its speakers]819-its speakers is yet to be resolved , and its lengthy discussion does not belong to the scope of this book . > Though [Yoruba]12-yoruba , like English , has the SVO ( Subject Verb Object ) as its basic structure , it is slightly different from it synfactically . The syntactical difference 15

lies in the position of an attributive word in [Yoruba]12-yoruba . ( l)-<3 ) below for example , show that [Yoruba]12-yoruba , like English , has subject verb object as its basic structure : SV O 1 . [Olowo - aiye pa Ojola - ibinu Olowo - aiye]283-olowo - aiye killed [Ojola - ibinu]283-olowo - aiye 2 . FagunWa kg Ogboju Ode [Fagunwa]271-fagunwa wrote Ogboju Ode . 3 . [Olowo - aiye]283-olowo - aiye ni [Omg Akgwediran Olowo - aiye]284-omg akgwediran olowo - aiye is [the son of [Akowediran]285-akowediran]820-the son of akowediran The slight syntactical difference lies in the adjectival phrases or clauses . In [Yoruba]12-yoruba the governing noun comes before the attributive word or the adjectives as ( 4)-(6 ): 4 . BibeliMiaig a. Bible Holy- b. Holy Bible 5 . Iwin buburu ni Anjgnnu - [Ibem]58-ibem [a. gnome vicious]821-a. gnome vicious is [Anjonnu - Iberu]59-anjonnu - iberu b. Anjpnnu - iberu is a vicious gnome 6 . [Mo mu ada]286-mo mu ada mo nFn & imngbgn a. [I]0-i took machete [I]0-i using shave beard [my]0-i b. [I]0-i took a machete , ( and ) [I]0-i was shaving [my]0-i beard with it . c. or [I]0-i took a machete and [I]0-i was using it to shave [my]0-i beard . ( 4 ) and ( 5 ) show clearly the syntactical pattern in the use of adjectives in [Yoruba]12-yoruba . ( 4 ) and ( 5 ) and ( 6a ) for example , are ungrammatical in [Yoruba]12-yoruba , and by the same token ( 4a ) , ( 5a ) , and ( 6a ) are ungrammatical in English . ( 6 ) , however , is a complex sentence , therefore it needs further analysis . ( 6 ) is what [Bamgbose]213-bamgbose describes as a ' compound sentence structure , '[213-bamgbose] except it deviates slightly from [his]213-bamgbose basic definition of a comp ound sentence structure , for ' compound sentence structure '[213-bamgbose] [he]213-bamgbose believes , ' consists ’[213-bamgbose] of two or more sentence structures linked by the linking element(s ) sugbgn ' but '[213-bamgbose] tabi , abi ' or '[213-bamgbose] yala ... tabi ' whether '[213-bamgbose] ... or'^^ The difference between ( 6 ) and [Bamgbose]213-bamgbose 's definition lies in the fact that ( 6 ) does not have any linking element : the two free clauses are simply collocated in [Fagunwa]271-fagunwa 's construction . Notice that ( 6a ) is syntactically different only in the second clause , where [mi]822-mi ' [my]823-my '[823-my] a possessive - suffix of the noun irungbgn ' beard '[823-my] which functions as an adjective — is used . [Its]823-my syntactic pattern is as follows : subj . + verb+past + dir . obj . + subj . + verb+ing + indr . obj . + poss . Mo , + mu + ada + mo , + nFnfa + intgbgn + [mi]822-mi , • ( ® ) 1 + take + machete +1 , + use+ing + beard + [my]0-i ( b ) [I]0-i took a machete ; [I]0-i was using it to shave [my]0-i beard ( c ) [I]0-i took a machete , and [I]0-i was shaving [my]0-i beard with it , . Another linguistic phenomenon which [a translator]824-a translator has to take seriously is the use of the tone in Yoruba . 16

[Yoruba]271-fagunwa is a tdilal language , therefore it is very rhythmic . [Eldred D. Jone]287-eldred d. jone 's description of the language is thus very precise : AU Yoruba culture is enshrined in the language , a highly tonal and musical language which gives the impression of being chanted rather than spoken . The rhythmic and tonal qualities do not come over into English , which is [a different language]825-a different language . It is this rhythm which constitutes one of the grandeurs of the language . [Yoruba]271-fagunwa has three basic tones ; low ( \ ) , middle ( — ) , and high ( ) . These tone marks are written over the vowels in order to realise the appropriate tone , ’ hence the appropriate meaning . Should the tone marks be misplaced , the meaning would be ’[271-fagunwa] changed completely . Tone , in a sense , may be compared to stress in English,-except that stress may not change the meaning of a word completely as its does in [Yoruba.^]60-yoruba.^ " * The list of words in ( 7 ) , ( 8) , and ( 9 ) demonstrate the way in which tone affects meaning in [Yoruba]12-yoruba . .a b64 wa ' come '[826-he] ba ' overtake '[826-he] yva ' search '[826-he] ba ' crouch '[826-he] wa ' excavate '[826-he] ba ' alight '[826-he] a b65 qkq ' hoe '[826-he] awg ' guinea fowl '[826-he] qkq ' [husband]4154-husband '[826-he] awo ' mystery '[826-he] qkq ' spear '[826-he] awo ' eys glass '[826-he] a b old ' honour '[826-he] owo ' hand '[826-he] < 51a ' [a town]4155-a town in [Qsun]61-qsun State owo '[826-he] broom ' qla '[826-he] wealth ' dwo '[826-he] respect ' As shown above , a word can mean three or more different things , depending on the tone . By the same token , the Meanings of sentences can be affected by the appropriate or inappropriate use of tone as ( 10a ) ( b ) and ( Ila ) and ( b ) illustrate here ; _ _ 10a 3 _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ n ji___------------------ 1 ° ---------------------------- - 2 Eja _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ lo _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ 1 _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ o _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ ra _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ ja _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ [Eja]4156-eja d jf jf 16 ra l^a fish electric is [you]4157-you by at [market]4158-market [You]4157-you bought an electric fish from [the market]4159-the market 10b 3 _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ i2 - ----------------------------- 2 [eja]4156-eja _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ ji _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ lo _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ 1 _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ o _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ ji _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ ra _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ ja _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ fish a sudden is [you]4157-you bought at [market]4158-market [you]4157-you bought a sudden fish from [the market]4159-the market 17[826-he]

please help [me]0-i wash plate [my]0-i plase help [me]0-i wash [my]0-i plateIla 3 _ _ _ _ o , wa le 2mi wa [he]826-he drove [me]0-i come [home]569-home [he]826-he dro^e [me]0-i [home]569-home 11b o wa . wa le 2 mi 1 _ _ [he]826-he search [me]0-i come [home]569-home [he]826-he came to look for [me]0-i at [home]569-home or [he]826-he came to visit [me]0-i at [home]569-home 12a3 wo ba fo omi WO mi 1 a jb wo ba mi fo a please help [me]0-i smash plate [my]0-i please help [me]0-i smash [my]0-i platewo mi 12b 3 ' wo ba fo 2 mi wo mi 1 jo fo a jd wo bd mi fo a wo mi The data ( 7)-{12 ) illustrated the way tone operates in the language . Therefore , it is obvious from the analysis thus far , that [Yoruba]271-fagunwa derives , as a tone language , meaning from the tone , and when the tone is misplaced , an '[0-i] embarrassing mispronunciation which causes general amusement ' , as [Rowland]288-rowland aptly puts it , occurs . Example ( 10b ) and ( 12a ) illustrate this amusing mispronunciation , while ( Ila ) and ( b ) simply convey different meanings . Because the tone marker on the word wa in ( Ila ) is low , it means '[0-i] drive ' ; the marker on the.same work wd in ( 11b ) is high , hence its meaning , '[0-i] come ' . This linguistic feature is what [a translator]824-a translator needs to perceive in [his]824-a translator translation , and those linguistic parameters make the task of trandating [Fagunwa]271-fagunwa difficult , among many other things which have to do with the nuances of some ideas in the novel which do not translate smoothly into the English language . As has been demonstrated above , [Yoruba]271-fagunwa is a rhythmic language , and the rhythm does not transfer completely English . But since rhythmic pattern is extensively used by [Fagunwa]271-fagunwa for rhetorical effect , efforts have been exerted to convey the rhythm into English as much as possible . 18[0-i]

Part VI : [Fagunwa]271-fagunwa 's Rhetoric [Fagunwa]271-fagunwa 's artistic prowess , vivjdness of imagination and all [we]832-we can attribute to [him]271-fagunwa in terms of literary excellence , are all manifested in [his]271-fagunwa powerful and - compelling use of language ? [[His]271-fagunwa Yoruba]833-his yoruba is impeccable ; [he]271-fagunwa is a master of [his]271-fagunwa mother tongue , for [his]271-fagunwa trade mark is rhetoric . It is almost impossible to read through any of [Fagunwa]271-fagunwa 's novels without catching the glipapse of [his]271-fagunwa dazzling and delightful use of language . [Beier]198-ulli beier is thus right when [he]198-ulli beier asserts that [Fagunwa]271-fagunwa is fond of rhetoric . [He]271-fagunwa likes words . [He]271-fagunwa likes to pile them up , say the same thing over and over again in infinite variation . [He]271-fagunwa is [a master of rhetoric , who can make repetitions and variations swing in a mountainous rhythm]834-a master of rhetoric , who can make repetitions and variations swing in a mountainous rhythm , like [Yoruba]271-fagunwa drumming.^^ [His]271-fagunwa language is adorned with proverbs , epigrams , and poetic diction . As [he]271-fagunwa sets out to tell [his]271-fagunwa story in [his]271-fagunwa first novel , for example , [he]271-fagunwa addresses [[his]271-fagunwa reader]596-his reader or [audience]836-audience : Enyin ore mi bi owe bi owe ni a nlu ilu - agidigbo , ologbon ni [i]0-i jo o , omoran lii si irno ' . Itan ti ngo so yi agidigbo ni ; emi ni eniti ^o lu ilu na , [myin]4163-myin ni ologbon ti yio jo , enyin ni omorai ) ti yio mo o pelu . ” meaning : [[My]271-fagunwa friends]4164-my friends all , like the sonordus proverb do [we]4165-we drum the agidigbo ; it is [the wise who dance to it]4166-the wise who dance to it , and [file learned who understand its language]4167-file learned who understand its language . The story which follows is a veritable ^digba , it js [I]271-fagunwa who will drum it , and [you]4168-you the wise who will interpret it . This passage exemplifies the way [Fagunwa]271-fagunwa gets to [[his]271-fagunwa audience]4080-his audience through an effective rhetoric . [He]271-fagunwa calls [[his]271-fagunwa readers]4170-his readers '[271-fagunwa] [[my]0-i friends]4164-my friends ' , and [he]271-fagunwa invites [them]4170-his readers to go with [him]271-fagunwa on [his]271-fagunwa imaginative journey through the story . [He]271-fagunwa states plainly that the story is an allegory through the metaphorical use of the agidigbo drum ; by doing that , [he]271-fagunwa is really saying that '[271-fagunwa] [my]0-i story is supposed to mean something : it is ap^able , but [I]0-i want [you]838-you to decipher its meaning . Thus the first few lines are packed , with rhetorical stories such as simile ( the story is like sonorous proverb ) , n^tapjior ( the narrative is like drumming ) , analogy ( it is akin to the sound of agidigbo ) . This way , [he]0-i appeals to the pathos and the ethos of [[his]0-i audience]4080-his audience ; [he]0-i is indeed [a competent rhetorician like [Cicero]289-cicero and [Quintilian]290-quintilian of old]840-a competent rhetorician like cicero and quintilian of old . [He]0-i believes that as [a rhetorician]841-a rhetorician , [he]0-i has a resporfeibility to teach not only by what [he]0-i says , but by who [he]0-i is as well — and'we know who [he]0-i is through fire tenor of what [he]0-i says . So [Ulli Beier]198-ulli beier is right as [he]198-ulli beier observes : [Fagunwa]271-fagunwa 's moralizing is often too deliberate and it would be difficult for [the adult reader]842-the adult reader to take , if it was not done with such charm . No event takes place , no situation is described from which [we]843-we are not supposed to learn something . A nauseating idea . [Yet^who]291-yet^who could object to being ' improved '[0-i] in such a charming manner ... Therefore in the first few lines of [his]0-i Ogboju Ode as cited above , [he]0-i is saying , in a way , ' Come , go with [me]0-i , as [I]0-i journey into [the forest of the universe]4171-the forest of the universe ; r^son with [me]0-i , as [I]0-i penetrate into the abyss of the human soul . '[0-i] Thus , [the audience 19]844-the audience 19

is lured into the realm of [the unseen world]716-the unseen world through the use of [his]0-i rhetorical power . Before this section is brought to an end , one more example of [Fagunwa]271-fagunwa 's verbal gymnastics could be cited from [Igbo Olodumare]253-igbo olodumare ( [The Forest of]545-the forest of [God]186-god ) . In the epigrammatic passage below , [Fagunwa]271-fagunwa states the principles that should ^ide the lives of [the young men]847-the young men and [women]589-women as .they think about family life : [Okunrin]292-okunrin ti oji ni kutu ojo aiyere ti o gbe oran obinrin le ibi pataki ni okan aiyare ko ni di pataki lai lai ; obinrin ti o ji ni kutukutu ti o gbe oran okunrin le ibi pataki okan aiya re ko ni di pataki lai lai ... ( p. 6 ) . meaning [A man who wakes up early in the morning of]849-a man who wakes up early in the morning of [his]849-a man who wakes up early in the morning of life . And gives an important place to [a woman]850-a woman 's matter in [his]849-a man who wakes up early in the morning of heart . Will not become important forever . [A woman who wakes up early in the morning of]851-a woman who wakes up early in the morning of [her]851-a woman who wakes up early in the morning of life . And gives an important place to [a man]852-a man 's matter in [her]851-a woman who wakes up early in the morning of heart Will not become important forever . The passage is not only ^igrammatic , it is rhythmic as well , hence its conversion to a verse from . ™ Thus far , [I]0-i believe that enough has been said to illustrate [Fagunwa]271-fagunwa 's use of a complex rhetorical technique in [his]271-fagunwa novels . 20

Part VII : Note on the Translation The main purpose of this work is to provide an annotated translation of [Fagunwa]271-fagunwa 's Igbo Olodtunare , a translation ' which respects the style of the original and the intention of [the author]575-the author , thereby affording a critical access to the novel by [literary scholars]4173-literary scholars and [students of letters]4174-students of letters as well as [general English readers]4175-general english readers . The desire to achieve ttiis objective , however , demands a specification of a philosophy of translation , and a careful choice of a method '[271-fagunwa] and procedure . ---- Stated briefly , [my]0-i objective in translating Igbo Olodumare is to translate what is in the novel rattier .than what ought to be . To put it in another way , [my]0-i task as [a translator]824-a translator is not to rewrite [Fagunwa]271-fagunwa 's Igbo Olodumarem . English in [my]0-i stylistic idiosyncrasy but to unveil [his]271-fagunwa meaning through [his]271-fagunwa own words and style in the translated edition^ Thus , it -is obvious that this specified philosophy of translation permits neither a free translation nor unnecessary paraphrasing . It is [my]0-i belief that the chosen method and procedure in this translation will make possible what [Nida]293-nida calls ' the principle of equivalent effect '[293-nida] ■ The method which [my]0-i specified philosophy of the text demands , is basically semanticommunicative translation , a method of translation which the nature , of the text ( a literary text which is naturally .connotative/^ demands . ' This method necessitates a literal translation which keeps the sense of words and expressions wjthin the cultural perspective of [me]4122-the narrator original language without blurring the intelligibility of the content in English , so that the content is communicative as well . In other words , the literalness of the translation does not jeopardize its being sensible to [the reader of the English edition]4176-the reader of the english edition , and though some words have taken new senses , figurative or metaphorical sinpe they emanate from the culture of the original language of the text ( [Yoruba]12-yoruba ) , where the intelligibility is somewhat m danger , the annotation is used as a means of protection . Such situations can be instanced in several places in the text . ’[4122-the narrator] One instance is seen when [the narrator]4122-the narrator meets [[his]4122-the narrator old friend]855-his old friend in the first chapter of the novel , and [[his]4122-the narrator friend]856-his friend tries to tell [him]4122-the narrator ( [the narrator]4122-the narrator ) that [he]4122-the narrator has not chart^ed , and that [his]4122-the narrator strength is still intact ; [Eagunwa]272-eagunwa makes [him]4122-the narrator say , ' emi iti gte re atijg [beniagbara]62-beniagbara [miko dinku]4177-miko dinku , egungtm tube lata oktmrin , '[4122-the narrator] which is render^ as follows : ' [I]4122-the narrator am [your]4122-the narrator old , [old mend]4178-old mend , and [my]4122-the narrator strengtti is still intact , because there are bones in [man]590-man 's body '[4122-the narrator] . A less relaxed and an extreme literal translation would read : ' ... lam [[your]4122-the narrator ofd friend]4180-your ofd friend , and [my]4122-the narrator strength is not lessened ; there is bone in [man]590-man 's body , . '[4122-the narrator] [I]0-i have been extremely literal in the latter translation of these lines , in order.to make the point that the word hope is used as a metaphor for ' strength '[4122-the narrator] or ' power '[4122-the narrator] within the , culture of the original language — [Yoruba]12-yoruba . That is the acceptable metaphor or physical description of [a powerful person]858-a powerful person . Notice - that ttie former rendering is more relaxed , and yet ' literal ; '[4122-the narrator] that way , the translation keeps the original sense of [the world]639-the world ' bone '[4122-the narrator] , and , in order to achieve clarity and protect the intelligibility of the idea , the word'hone ' is annotated . '[4122-the narrator] Another word'ia'path ' . This word takes a mew sense , because it is transplanted , so to speak , from.the cultural context of [Yoruba]12-yoruba . The word is , 2 - 1[4122-the narrator]

used when [[the narrator]4122-the narrator 's wife]861-the narrator 's wife advises [him]4122-the narrator not to be afraid to concentrate on the work which [Akara - ogun]207-akara - ogun , who is to tell the story of [his]207-akara - ogun fattier ( [Oliwo - aiye]294-oliwo - aiye ) , will give [him]4122-the narrator . [[The narrator]4122-the narrator 's wife]861-the narrator 's wife assures [[her]861-the narrator 's wife husband]864-her husband of [her]861-the narrator 's wife total support , when [she]861-the narrator 's wife perceives [the husband]865-the husband 's expression of anxiety at the sight of [[his]865-the husband friend]856-his friend , [Akara - ogun]207-akara - ogun , who will put [him]865-the husband through the task of writing the long , involved story of [[his]865-the husband father]4099-his father , [Olowo - aiye]284-omg akgwediran olowo - aiye . [Fagunwa]271-fagunwa makes [her]861-the narrator 's wife say ' ... Ng o tgju Here , [ng o tgju ona re]4182-ng o tgju ona re , ng o tgju gmg .. .. '[861-the narrator 's wife] ( p. 8) , In translation it reads , ' [I]861-the narrator 's wife shall take care of [your]4183-your path ; [I]861-the narrator 's wife shall take cafe of ( [[your]4183-your ) child]4184-your ) child ... '[861-the narrator 's wife] ' Path '[861-the narrator 's wife] is used in a metaphorical sense here to indicate everything that [the character]868-the character does , including [his]868-the character coming in and [his]868-the character going out . Therefore , in order to protect the intelligibility of the idea , ' path '[861-the narrator 's wife] is carefully annotated . Furthermore , [I]0-i need to emphasize the fact that ttiough it has been [my]0-i intention to keep the senses of words and expressions within the cultural perspective of the original language , injelligibility and ' the principle , of equivalent effect '[0-i] are the overriding aims of the method and the procedure employed in the translation . Hence the branding of the method as ' semanticommunicative '[0-i] . That means , of course , that [I]0-i have had to take some liberty to translate some passages in such a way as to enhance the achievement of intelligibility and equivalent effect thereby effecting a balanced translation — a translation which does not only respect the style of the original and the intention of [the author]575-the author , but maintains the interest of the English as well . Therefore , the expression like : ' ... ng o tgju gmg , ngosiwa ayepataki si gnigna gfun'(p . 9 ) , when translated extremely literally , reads '[871-the reader] .I shall take care trf [child]870-child , and [I]0-i shall prepare an important food into the path of [your]870-child throat . This rendering sounds too burdensome for [the reader]871-the reader in English burdensome in the sense that [the reader]871-the reader has to pause and try to make sense out of such a cumbersome statement . Therefore , in order to deliver [the reader]871-the reader from such unnecessary strain and pain , [I]0-i have had to translate it as follows : ... [I]0-i shall take care of ( [[our]874-our ) child]875-our ) child , and [I]0-i shall prepare some delicious food for [you]870-child to enjoy . ' This rendering is both relaxed enough to be clear , and literal enough to preserve [the author]575-the author 's style and intention as well . Anpther example of such a cautious translation is the statement which [the narrator]4122-the narrator makes while talking to [[his]4122-the narrator wife]628-his wife about the way [[their]874-our guest]4188-their guest , [Akara - ogun]207-akara - ogun , will be received in [[their]874-our home]4189-their home . In [his]4122-the narrator desire to prefect what should be the prevalent situation in [an ideal home]4190-an ideal home , [FagUnwa]271-fagunwa makes [the '[0-i] narrator]4191-the ' narrator say , ' ... A o fi igbadun [He]4122-the narrator wa han fun alejo wa , '[0-i] ( p. 8) rendered as ' ... [We]874-our shall demonstrate to [[our]874-our guest]4192-our guest that ttiis is a very ddighful hunity indeed . '[0-i] Again , thih preserves the stylistic prowess of [the author]575-the author , and maintains ttre interest of [the reader]871-the reader irt & rglish as well . In [my]0-i earlier discussion of the language of ttie text , [Yoruba]271-fagunwa , [I]0-i have briefly touched upon the linguistic parameters of ttie language as well as the rhetorical prowess of [Fagunwa]271-fagunwa in the novel , the rhetOTical prowess vttiidi does not make the task of [the translator]579-the translator an easy cme . Therefore , whenever needed , a narrative bridge^ is constructed in parenttieses , in order to ^nlwnce a smcmtti flow of [Fagunwa]271-fagunwa 's narrative in the translated edition . Thus the adopted method of translation and procedure , [I]0-i have bem able to work through the m^ of [his]271-fagunwa bizzare imagery , unusual structure , strange characters , movii^ through [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's struige setting , and , very quickk from one event to [me]0-i other , acting out ttie essence of ttieir nnme nrlah iro , wittt such an enttiusi^stic narrative style , to preserve [Fagunwa]271-fagunwa 's sensibility , style , meaning and motive as much as [I]0-i could . The ihythm of [Fagunwa]271-fagunwa 's unusual 22

verbal gymnastics can not , due to the nature of English as a nontonal language , be adequately conveyed in the translated edition , but enough efforts have been exerted to present the substance of [his]271-fagunwa thought pattern , to expand the readership of [Igbo Olodiunare]295-igbo olodiunare , and ultimately enlist the interest of [the reader]871-the reader in English .
