Since the sources from which to glean an accurate biography of [D.O. Fagunwa]187-fagunwa are extremely few at tire time of the writing of tins work , [Ba^bose]302-ba^bose is thus acknowledged as the nuqor source of 24-

Ulis biographical information . 32 . Ibid . , [Bamgbose]213-bamgbose defines ord as ' bull - roarer '[213-bamgbose] . Ord is a form of African Traditional Religion which is mainly known among [the Yoruba people]652-the yoruba people . It is related to ancestral worship , and its spirit is invoked by the use of a piece of bamboo tree carved into a flat ruler - like object , about six to eight inches long , with a tiny hole bored on one end of it , a hole through which a long string is tied . When it is swung around vigorously , it roars very loudly , and the presence of [Ord]303-ord is said to be invoked . [Women]589-women are strictly forbidden to come out atthe dusk during the week in which Ord annual festival is being held . 33 . In the same way that [Tutuola]224-tutuola 's PaZm Wine Drinkardis now rendered into ' fifteen - languages worldwide ; '[187-fagunwa] See Ad . Narrative bridge is a word or words or phrases added to die original narrative in parentheses to die translated edition , in order to maintain a smooth flow , int^gibility and clarity . 26

[The Forest of God]689-the forest of god

1 [The Beginning of [Olowo - aiye^]283-olowo - aiye]892-the beginning of olowo - aiye^ It was on a sweltering afternoon , after ! had eaten the second meal of the day , that [I]0-i left [[my]0-i house]893-my house and strolled to the outside of the city wall . [I]0-i climbed to the top of a huge rock ; when [I]0-i reached the top ( of [the rock]894-the rock ) , [I]0-i sat down under a tree that grew there , hugging [my]0-i legs to [my]0-i chest . The sun was scour^gly hot indeed ; [human bodies]895-human bodies were as hot as heated yam flour pot/ Sweat soaked [all the children of [the world]639-the world]896-all the children of the world as if [they]896-all the children of the world had poured water on [themselves]896-all the children of the world . [I]0-i , who had worn a cap before , who had tilted [my]0-i cap pointedly towards [my]0-i forehead^ took [my]0-i cap off the crown of [my]0-i head and peaceful air was blowing across [my]0-i head . [I]0-i also took off [my]0-i clotiies , except [my]0-i pants which remained on [my]0-i buttocks . The afternoon was sun - ripened indeed . [The farmers]898-the farmers had left [[their]898-the farmers farms]899-their farms ; [they]898-the farmers were laughing in [4ieir farmhuts]900-4ieir farmhuts . [The carriers]901-the carriers were unable to talk ; [they]901-the carriers w«e panting as fliey were climbing [toe hill]902-toe hill . [The pathway]903-the pathway was as hard aS stone , and toe roots of the trees were as solid as iron - dross . The ground was as red as palm oil,-^ the niffs of white trousers were dust - stained ; the hems of [men]634-men 's flowing garments were red . [I]0-i sympathized with [the lorry crew]905-the lorry crew : [toeir bodies]906-toeir bodies were full of dust . [They]906-toeir bodies were as dirty as the shrubs by [toe roadside]907-toe roadside . [Those who were sitting at toe back of [toe lorry]909-toe lorry]908-those who were sitting at toe back of toe lorry were powdered as with irksome face powder ; [they]906-toeir bodies were as rust - coloured as mud walls . Dust covered [all the children of [toe world]911-toe world]910-all the children of toe world ; [toe host of living creatures]912-toe host of living creatures felt toe scourging power of toe sun . The lizards were running about , arid [toeir bodies]906-toeir bodies were making rustling sounds on toe dry leaves . The big birds had ceased to cry ; for [I]0-i had heard toe call of toe larkhroled cuckoo ; [I]0-i had listened to the voice of toe dove ; toe red - feathered bird had cried ; [aluho^]321-aluho^ had spoken,- ® but every one of [them]912-toe host of living creatures kept deadly silent where [God]186-god had shelter^ [them]912-toe host of living creatures ; only the little birds that were not bigger than swallows were [toe ones flying here and there]914-toe ones flying here and there , [they]914-toe ones flying here and there were unstable like a leaf on toe surface of dw water . [They]914-toe ones flying here and there were hopping from one tree to toe other and were crying lik « baby ducks . Thus was [I]0-i , sittirig down quietly , looking at the eye of life and musing about [toe children of [men]634-men]915-toe children of men , for [I]0-i have lived with various kinds of [people]917-people . The tone to which [I]0-i am now referring was a crucial period 29

in [my]0-i life , for it was at that time that [[my]0-i father]548-my father shut [his]548-my father eyes , crossed to [the other side of [file river]920-file river]919-the other side of file river , and hade file world goodbye ; and [the cock crew inhisabsence]921-the cock crew inhisabsence . The matterwas painful to [me]0-i ; itpenetrated to the depth trf [my]0-i marrow . [[My]0-i father]548-my father had no equal among [men]634-men . [He]548-my father and [[my]0-i mother]924-my mother loved [each other]925-each other , andfiiey laid a good example before [[us]926-us children]927-us children : before [me]0-i , [Adeyemi]322-adeyemi , [OjuoLape]323-ojuolape , and [Omotunde]324-omotunde . [[Re^li Osunypmi^]325-re^li osunypmi^ who was [[my]0-i mother]924-my mother]928-re^li osunypmi^ who was my mother , was [a woman who loved [[her]928-re^li osunypmi^ who was my mother husband]864-her husband and [[her]928-re^li osunypmi^ who was my mother children]932-her children very much . Tears of mercy filled [[my]0-i mother]924-my mother 's eyes]930-a woman who loved her husband and her children very much . tears of mercy filled my mother 's eyes . [She]924-my mother is still alive today ; but [[my]0-i father]548-my father is not . [[My]0-i father]548-my father 's death hurt [me]0-i deepty , for [he]548-my father treated [me]0-i as [a father]936-a father should treat [[his]548-my father child]937-his child ; [I]0-i also tried as unidi as [I]0-i could to please [him]548-my father so that [he]548-my father would realize that [I]0-i appreciated all [he]548-my father had done for [me.l]0-i was thinking about many things within [me]0-i : if [[my]0-i father]548-my father had not died untimely , [I]0-i would have graced [his]548-my father life with those things that were conjured up in [my]0-i imagination . For if [a man]852-a man dresses in rags like [a peasant]940-a peasant and [he]852-a man is clothed with borrowed clothes , as long as [he]852-a man does not forget [those who begat [him]852-a man]941-those who begat him , [God]186-god will never forget [him]852-a man either . But as [I]0-i was pondering these things , ( little did [I]0-i know that ) [the Creator]942-the creator 's language was different : from [mine]0-i , and [God]186-god was wiser than [I.]0-i One day , in the morning , a message came to [me]0-i from [home]569-home that [[my]0-i father]548-my father had gone to [the vault of heaven]945-the vault of heaven . Thus [I]0-i became down - hearted , sank deep in grief . Mid [my]0-i body became feverish with anxiety ; [my]0-i stomach was upset and troubled just as when the wind moves the trees in [the forest]4092-the forest . Life was disgusting to [me]0-i like a filfliy rag , and heaven was as beautiful as gold in [my]0-i eyes . These were the thirds that [I]0-i was contemplating on that hot afternoon that [I]0-i have been speaking about , as [I]0-i had been sitting on [the rock]894-the rock . [Little]326-little did [I]0-i know that as [I]0-i was sitting down , there was somebody in [a small bushy area close to where [I]0-i was]948-a small bushy area close to where i was ; [I]0-i was not aware of this before . [I]0-i simply sat down , staring ahead ; [I]0-i did not take time to spy into nooks and around [the comers near [me]0-i]949-the comers near me . If [I]0-i had known this before , [I]0-i would simply have turned [my]0-i head in another direction ; [I]0-i would have sat down where [nobody]950-nobody would have been able to find [me]0-i , for [I]0-i wanted to think deeply at that time , and [I]0-i did not want [anyone]951-anyone to interrupt [me]0-i at all , for [one]4131-one should play at the time for play , fight at file time for fitting , weep at file time for weeping , and rejoice at the time for rejoicing . [[He]953-his who is going to a party and wears the cap of [a farmer]955-a farmer]954-he who is going to a party and wears the cap of a farmer , is dressed in clothes like [a traveller]956-a traveller 's , and wraps a cloth around [his]953-his leans like [one who is going to hunt game]957-one who is going to hunt game , [fiiat person]958-fiiat person has taken [his]953-his sacrifice beyond the crossroads.^ As [I]0-i was tfunking very seriously at that moment ; [I]0-i did not want anyeme to disturb ( the flow of [my]0-i thought ) at all . But whefiier [I]0-i liked it or not , [this man]959-this man deliberately confronted [me]0-i . [I]0-i was angry at [him]959-this man , and [I]0-i frowned like [a hungry person]960-a hungry person ; [I]0-i was sitting like [a man under stress]961-a man under stress . [I]0-i frowned like [a house - boy who broke [[his]963-his 30

master]964-his 30 master 's dishes and dared not tell [him]963-his , hut continued to hang by the walls , while [his]959-this man stomach is disturbed and troubled like die foam of palmwine in a jar]962-a house - boy who broke his 30 master 's dishes and dared not tell him , hut continued to hang by the walls , while his stomach is disturbed and troubled like die foam of palmwine in a jar . When [the man]4074-the man greeted [me]0-i , [I]0-i answered [him]4074-the man very softly . Why did [I]0-i answer [him]4074-the man at all ? So that it mij^t not seem as if [I]0-i had over - reacted , lest [people]917-people call [me]0-i [a4nean fellow]967-a4nean fellow , so thatj > [eople]968-eople might not think that [I]0-i was not [a gentleman]969-a gentleman . This was what impelled ih&to answer [him]4074-the man at all . [I]0-i merely greeted [him]4074-the man ; it was not [tom]279-isaac b. thomas die depth cxf [my]0-i heart . After [Ihad]0-i greeted [him]4074-the man , [I]0-i began bRjChave in such a way as to make [him]4074-the man angry and go away : [I]0-i kept silent^idid not speak ; [he]4074-the man spoke [I]0-i did not laugh . [I]0-i got up from where [I]0-i was sitting and played aloM die base of the rock widiout asking for permission from [him]4074-the man as [I]0-i ought to have done , and when [I]0-i came back again , [I]0-i found [him]4074-the man still on die saihe spot . [I]0-i simply sat down again , without saying a word to [him]4074-the man , without greeting [him]4074-the man , without talking to [him]4074-the man , and without lookingat [his]4074-the man face at all . [I]0-i was singing aJtdvihistiing^did notevenask [him]4074-the man to sit down . [[My]283-olowo - aiye father]548-my father also supported [himself]548-my father with [his]548-my father left leg as [die gnome]4658-die gnome tried to push [him]548-my father into [[die pit’so]4659-die pit’so]4659-die pit’so [he]548-my father would fall into it — [he]548-my father would have filled the pit to the brim — but that was impossible , for before [he]548-my father pushed [[my]283-olowo - aiye father]548-my father intp the pit ) [[my]283-olowo - aiye father]548-my father had extricated [his]548-my father rightleg out of [his]548-my father grip , and had Stood firmly on the ground ; and when [he]548-my father took a look at the.gome 's eyes [he]548-my father burst"into laughter and said , '[283-olowo - aiye] A cat 's back nevertouches the ground : if s a taboo , ' and [all the gnomes]4663-all the gnomes shouted . [Takefoim]370-takefoim

and [[his]370-takefoim wife]628-his wife upstairs in [[my]0-i palace]1645-my palace over there ; let [him]370-takefoim live [there]642-there , and after some time , [I]0-i will come to conduct a marriage^^^ for [[Akow^ diran]371-akow^ diran 's child]1647-akow^ diran 's child . “ So [they]1648-they did ; [they]1648-they began to take care of [[my]0-i father]548-my father and left [[his]370-takefoim wife]628-his wife with [him]370-takefoim , living together for three months before [they]1648-they conducted [their]1648-they wedding for [them]1648-they . “ Within these three months , [[my]0-i father]548-my father ate food and was plump , and the back of [his]370-takefoim neck was very fat indeed . Even before [[my]0-i father]548-my father left [the world]639-the world , there - was not a day when [he]548-my father told the story , that [I]0-i would not burst into laughter . [He]548-my father used to say thus : ' [I]548-my father ate and [my]548-my father stomach got terribly protruded like that of a baby bird : a big stomach that drove the navel all the way inside . [My]548-my father hip became big and bulky . [[My]548-my father wife]549-my wife could not go throu^ a narrow doorway anymore , because [her]549-my wife legs were fatter than the cement pillars of a budding ; and [her]549-my wife hip was ^heavy enough to be a full load for [six muscular men]4722-six muscular men . And the back o ) [her]549-my wife peck was as big as the size of [eight people put together]4723-eight people put together . [She]549-my wife hersell had changed the way [she]549-my wife walked : [she]549-my wife lifted [her]549-my wife legs at intervals as [she]549-my wife walked along , like those of a grazing cow , and [she]549-my wife never behaved like [a small person]4724-a small person anymore : [she]549-my wife was behaving like [the wife of [an important person ( in the society]4726-an important person ( in the society]4725-the wife of an important person ( in the society ) . [Noble men]4727-noble men do not want to walk like [the common nien]4728-the common nien ; [wealthy people]4729-wealthy people do not want to walk like [the poor people]4730-the poor people , and [women]589-women love to hluff very much . [[My]548-my father wife 's older sister]4732-my wife 's older sister changed too , for [her]4732-my wife 's older sister face was smooth like the young leaves on a lime tree , and [her]4732-my wife 's older sister entire body was clean and ligHt like the body of . [a three - day old baby]4733-a three - day old baby , for [all of [us]4734-all of us]4734-all of us ate tasty and nutritious food ; [We]4734-all of us ate delicious soup ; [we]4734-all of us ate the arms of animals ; [we]4734-all of us ate the livers of animals ; [we]4734-all of us ate ( chicken ) gizzards , and [we]4734-all of us also ate [their]4735-their adam 's apples too . " " This was the way [[my]548-my father father]548-my father used to tell the story , [all of [us]4734-all of us]4734-all of us would laugh ; all of [us]4734-all of us would somersault ; all of [us]4734-all of us would roll around on the floor . “ On [[my]548-my father father]548-my father 's wedding day , there was a big merriment forough- out [Igbo Olodumare]341-god . There were all kinds of food in [[the king]760-the king 's palace]4740-the king 's palace ; there were poundted yam with okra soup and meat , rice and melon oil prwared with onion and pepper , and a jumbo with 1 soup filled with meat . Beans with small fish and shrimp caught in [die ocean]4741-die ocean , which [they]1655-they had roasted and had dried stiff , were cooked together and were placed around . Fried yams were nothing , and [no one]1466-no one cared for fried plantain on this wedding day . And [we]4734-all of us can not count all the contemporary foods like butter and bread and all kinds of European cake up to biscuits of today which [wise women]4743-wise women make out of coconut and European salt . Big drums and savi .seker^^^ and tom - tom , violin and bok^^'^ and all other kinds of drums made by both black and [white people]4744-white people , all these things were brought to this party : it was a great day ( indeed ) . ''[548-my father] But [I]0-i am sorry to tell [you]1654-you that the party ended with a fight that day , because the animals were separated , and a table was prepared 61

for [them]1655-they . The lion was [the chaifman]1656-the chaifman , and the elephant was [the assistant chairman]1657-the assistant chairman , and the other little animals were [waiters]1658-waiters . This was where the fight began ; whenever the lion asked for something to be given to [him]1656-the chaifman , and [[me]0-i head of [the waiters]1660-the waiters]1659-me head of the waiters , the antelope , tried to give [him]1656-the chaifman what [he]1656-the chaifman asked for , [he]1659-me head of the waiters would Scratch [him]1656-the chaifman with [his]1659-me head of the waiters nails ; [he]1659-me head of the waiters would pull [him]1656-the chaifman toward [himself]1659-me head of the waiters as if lie wished to eat [him]1656-the chaifman , but [he]1659-me head of the waiters would say , T'm just kidding . After a while , the antelope could not bear it any longer , so [he]1659-me head of the waiters reported [him]1656-the chaifman to [the bridegroom]1661-the bridegroom , and [the bridegroom]1661-the bridegroom rebuked [the chairman]1483-the chairman . So it was with the birds ; [the ostrich]1664-the ostrich , [the father of birds , who was invited from [Igbo Irunmole]368-igbo irunmole]1665-the father of birds , who was invited from igbo irunmole to come [ana]372-ana chair ( the birds ) could not come because of some domestic hindrance . -The eagle thus became [the chairman]1483-the chairman in [his]1664-the ostrich place . [The pets]1667-the pets could not attend either so [they]1667-the pets sent six hens as [[their]1667-the pets representatives]1668-their representatives . Whenever the eagle left [his]1664-the ostrich seat , [he]1664-the ostrich would come to these six hens under the pretense that [he]1664-the ostrich was simply playing with [them]1667-the pets . So was it with the fox ; [he]1664-the ostrich began to behave as [a hypocrite]1132-a hypocrite too ; [he]1664-the ostrich asked the lion who was [the chairman]1483-the chairman to excuse , [him]1664-the ostrich , only to come to the place where the birds were sitting , and [he]1664-the ostrich stared at the chickens — it was very bad behavior indeed . " But at long last , the animals and the birds became drunk , and [they]1667-the pets began to act foolishly ; the elephant began to push the trees down , the lion began to kill ottier animals , the fox killed one of the hens , and eagle started chasing the birds around . At last , [the bridegroom]1661-the bridegroom became angry and drove all of [them]1667-the pets away . " When [the gnomes]4648-the gnomes were coming to tips party , [men]634-men were highly terrified : why ? It was because of [these gnomes]1674-these gnomes ' apparent wealth ; [some]4745-some wore gowns mad^ of beads ; some had clowns made with money ( coins ) ; some would eat with diamond spoon . Others '[1674-these gnomes] gowns looked like silver . None of [them]4648-the gnomes had a leather shoe on . If one did not have a pair of shoes made of gold on , that one would have on one made of silver ; another would put on one made of beads ; except [those who did not have feet]1675-those who did not have feet — those did not have any shoes — [they]1675-those who did not have feet were simply hopping around like frogs . Many were those who were exactly like [human beings]1062-human beings , and [the king of [Igbo Olodumare]341-god]786-the king of igbo olodumare was not different from [you]1678-you and [I.]1679-i. Still , some of [them]4648-the gnomes did not compare with [humans]745-humans ; [they]4648-the gnomes were bluffing in [their]4648-the gnomes own way . So one - legged [Osanyii/^^]373-osanyii/^^ did not forget [his]373-osanyii/^^ only leg because [he]373-osanyii/^^ had a diamond shoe on it . The event was colourful at [Igbo Olodumare]341-god because [the gnomes]4648-the gnomes were drunk , and [they]4648-the gnomes wtere dancing to the best of [their]4648-the gnomes abilities . Therefore , [I]377-tlje- think foat [I]377-tlje- sljould start to write [my]377-tlje- autobiography down , because [my]377-tlje- eyes have seen some ­ thing in the past . " When [I]0-i entered into [this forest]1399-this forest , [I]0-i did not see anything at all , [I]0-i never saw animals , neither did [I]0-i see a bird : squirrels did not even pass on the tree before [me]0-i . [I]0-i walked for a long time . But [I]0-i did not see a thing . " After a while , a ( strong ) wind began to blow ; all those rootless trees began to do obeisance , and they were standing back up . " The situation was very , very difficult ; were it not because of [my]0-i Creator 's mercies , the trees would have hit and killed [me]0-i — [God]341-god is indeed [a great King]1789-a great king . 67

" After a while , when one of those tall trees did obeisance by [my]0-i side , [I]0-i quickly sat on it before it stoop up , and when the wind , blew again , [I]0-i went up with the tree . And lhe tree was very tall ; if [a person]1088-a person looked at [me]0-i from the ground , [I]0-i would have looked very tiny ( up there ) . First , [I]0-i was happy when [I]0-i reached up there , because [I]0-i saw the whole panorama of [the area]1791-the area very clearly ; all the shrubs were deeply green , and the landscape was very beautiful . But after a while , [I]0-i realized that [insteackof]380-insteackof rejoicing ( for being up there ) , [I]0-i should be crying- Because after [I]0-i got up there , the wind ceased to blow . [Liana]381-liana stood the way it was before ; the trees ceased to do obeisance . If [I]0-i had known , [I]0-i should have quickly jumped down when the wind was blowing , but now that the tree was standing up , [my]0-i coming down would not be without some difficulty , for [I]0-i could not jump from such a high place ; if [I]0-i did , [my]0-i arms and legs would have broken into'pieces . The tree was so tall , and its trunk was so sleek , that [no one]1466-no one could get down from [its]1793-its top by [himself]1466-no one at all . This depressed [me]0-i , and [I]0-i began to regret what had prompted [me]0-i to behave so stupidly . ' After [I]186-god had finished [my]186-god speech , ( [Mr. ) Rat]384-mr. ) rat went on [his]384-mr. ) rat way , looking for [his]384-mr. ) rat daily bread . another tree . '[1844-my] For one whole year , it was fruit that constituted [my]0-i main food . " But something happened when it became three whole years that [I]0-i had been in [the forest]4092-the forest ; this was it : it happened one day , when [I]0-i strolled into - [the forest]4092-the forest , in search of fruit ; [I]0-i saw a lot of tortoises , but [I]0-i did not see many snails , and [I]0-i was very angry , because the snail was bigger than the kind of tortoises [we]1869-we used to see ( around ) . It was . not too long after [I]0-i got into [the cave]4932-the cave , when a torrent drove [me]0-i out , and [I]0-i went to hide in another cave . " " Thus [he]2068-that man had spoken , and these words penetrated into [my]0-i heart , and when [I]0-i began to respond , [I]0-i took a deep breath , cleared [my]0-i throat , so drat [I]0-i would not have any impediment in [my]0-i throat . 5 The Second Day at [[Baba]261-baba - qnirungbon - yeuke - [Onirun- gbon]116-onirun- gbon - y^uk^ 's Place]115-baba - onirun- gbon - y^uk^ 's place , the One who Lives on [the Peak of the Rock]117-the peak of the rock " When it was dawn the following day , after [we]2098-we had eaten , [Baba - Qnirungbon]261-baba - qnirungbon - yeuke reminded [me]0-i about [the friends whom [he]261-baba - qnirungbon - yeuke said [we]2098-we should go and greet]2099-the friends whom he said we should go and greet , and [he]261-baba - qnirungbon - yeuke also suggested that [we]2098-we shoulc^ go to [[Death]205-death 's house]2100-death 's house first . So , [we]2098-we got [ourselves]2098-we ready , and [we]2098-we began to go . " The first thing that surprised [me]0-i was the fact that [the path to [Death]205-death 's house]2101-the path to death 's house was soaked with blood ; die shrubs by the way side were soaked with blood as well ; still [Baba - Qnirungbon]261-baba - qnirungbon - yeuke was stepping along in the blood without giving it a thought , and [Ids]400-ids beard began to make [me]0-i laugh as it was dragging on the ground along in the blood . • ' Nothing ( actually ) frightened [me]400-ids anymore at that time , for [he]261-baba - qnirungbon - yeuke who has got out of the midst of [men]634-men , and has headed on to [the path that leads to [Igbo Olodumare]341-god]5095-the path that leads to igbo olodumare , and on [his]261-baba - qnirungbon - yeuke reaching there , begins to search around for [Death]205-death , that [One]258-one has fettered [his]258-one own feet and has tied chains around [his]258-one own waist ; [he]258-one has squeezed soma drops of pepper juice into [his]258-one own eyes , and [he]258-one is looking around for disaster . [Thus Baba - Onirungbon]398-baba - onirungbon kept going , and [I]400-ids , who did not have a beard , also followed [him]261-baba - qnirungbon - yeuke along . " After a while , [we]2103-we came upon [[Death]205-death 's house]2100-death 's house ; [we]2103-we were looking at [the house]973-the house afar off/ and vyhen [I]400-ids came closer , [I]400-ids saw seven heaps which were tall : they went far into the sky , and they were filled with bones . [The first heap]5098-the first heap was filled with human bones , the second filled with animals '[400-ids] bones , the third one was ( for ) snakes , the fourth was ( for ) fish , the fifth one was for birds , the sixth was for ants , and file ^venth ( one ) was for flies , but [this seventh heap]2102-this seventh heap had no bones like the ones before that : [it]2102-this seventh heap had thread - like veins , which were foe things foat stood as bones . " When [we]2103-we walked a Jittle closer to [foe house]2104-foe house . [Death]205-death came out of [foe house]2104-foe house , for [he]205-death was coming to meet [us]2103-we . hand , for [he]205-death is [a vicious creature]2106-a vicious creature . [He]205-death drank water from a humin skull.- As the mysterious creature came out of [[his]205-death house]1253-his house , [Baba - Onirungbon]398-baba - onirungbon turned [his]398-baba - onirungbon face to [me]0-i and said , " See , that 's the important creature coming right here . [Death]205-death , whose house is between [tnQ earth]2108-tnq earth and [the heaven]2109-the heaven . " [Death]205-death is . [a vicious creature]2106-a vicious creature , arid [he]205-death did not have any flesh on , [he]205-death was just bare bones . [His]205-death eyes were as big as a plate of food , like the moon , and were as red as fire and were rolling like a big fruit on a tree , dangling hnd being blown here and there by the wind . The ( set of ) teeth in [his]205-death mouth were like a lion 's ; they were red indeed , for [Death]205-death did.not enjoy yam , and [he]205-death did not enjoy banana ; [he]205-death did not enjoy okra nor did [he]205-death enjoy spinach ; [he]205-death enjoyed meat more than anyti^g else . " [Death]205-death was coming toward [us]2111-we , and [Baba - Onirungbon]398-baba - onirungbon and [I]0-i were going to meet [him]205-death ( as well ) . '[2132-the sixth one] " [The seventh one]2134-the seventh one was in a very precarious situation indeed . running around again . [I]0-i was so panicked to the extent that [I]0-i almost ran out . ' Going on with [my]398-baba - onirungbon story , a little while after [we]2146-we had been in [[Death]205-death 's house]2100-death 's house , [Baba - Onirungbon]398-baba - onirungbon introduced [me]398-baba - onirungbon to [him]959-this man , [he]398-baba - onirungbon said , " [You]398-baba - onirungbon [[my]398-baba - onirungbon dear friend]5134-my dear friend . " [Olowo]283-olowo - aiye - aiye , there is something fliat [I]0-i want to tell [you]283-olowo - aiye today ; [I]0-i want [you]283-olowo - aiye to take note of something and learn to be wise by it . is like a chain with which [he]2320-a g^tleman has bound [himself]2320-a g^tleman ; without [his]2320-a g^tleman fulfilling [his]2320-a g^tleman promise the chain remains bound . 6 The Third Day at [[Baba]261-baba - qnirungbon - yeuke - Onirun- gbon - yeuke 's Place]115-baba - onirun- gbon - y^uk^ 's place r * " [I]0-i did not sleep ( a wink ) till the following day . The only one time that [I]0-i closed [my]0-i eyes , [I]0-i began to dream a bad dream . [I]0-i saw a bad fairy in [my]0-i dream ; [he]2335-he was chasing [me]0-i around . As [the fairy]1439-the fairy was chasing [me]0-i along , [I]0-i met one snake on the way , and [his]2335-he teeth were like die teeth of a lion ; as [I]0-i was running away from that , [I]0-i saw an animal which was not fat : it looked lilje a sick animal whose nails were very long ; this one also terrified [me;2f]2337-me;2f 7 after that , [I]0-i woke up . When [I]0-i woke up , [I]0-i was panting like [one who was running a race]2338-one who was running a race , and [my]0-i heart was beating very loudly like an aeroplane . Ha ! [My]0-i eyes saw something in [Igbo Olodiunare]295-igbo olodiunare — [my]0-i eyes saw something ( indeed ) . After [I]0-i had eaten breakfast with [Baba - Onirungbonon]411-baba - onirungbonon this second day , [I]0-i told [him]411-baba - onirungbonon to let [us]2339-we go to ( [[Mr. ) Death]205-death 's house]2340-mr. ) death 's house before [we]2339-we set [our]2339-we hands on anything that [we]2339-we planned to do ( on that day ) , [he]411-baba - onirungbonon too agreed with [me]0-i . When [we]2339-we got [there]642-there , [we]2339-we did not firid die fairy at [home]569-home , but [we]2339-we left a message for [him]411-baba - onirungbonon so that whenever [he]411-baba - onirungbonon returned , [they]2343-they should give [our]2339-we message to [him]411-baba - onirungbonon . Thus [I]0-i came back joyfully to [[[my]0-i friend]4227-my friend 's house]2345-my friend 's house , [Baba - Onirungbon - yeuke]398-baba - onirungbon , who was living on [the hillock of the rock]2346-the hillock of the rock . " [This friend of [mine]0-i]2347-this friend of mine was very hospitable to [me]0-i ; [he]2347-this friend of mine did not let [me]0-i touch the cake which [[my]0-i mother]924-my mother brought for [me]0-i horn die dome of heaven . " When [we]2339-we came back , and after [we]2339-we had finished eating the second time , [Baba - Onirungbon]398-baba - onirungbon took [me]0-i up to [[his]398-baba - onirungbon upper storey]2349-his upper storey , and when [we]2339-we got [there]642-there , [he]398-baba - onirungbon took a seat , and [I]0-i took a seat ; both of [us]2339-we were facing [each other]925-each other ; [he]398-baba - onirungbon then told [me]0-i that the important thing that [we]2339-we were to do was the matter [he]398-baba - onirungbon was going to discuss with [me]0-i . After [he]398-baba - onirungbon had told [me]0-i this , [I]0-i was also happy ; [I]0-i adjusted [my]0-i seat very well , [I]0-i told [[my]0-i new friend]2352-my new friend that [I]0-i was listening , and that [he]398-baba - onirungbon should go on witii [his]398-baba - onirungbon speech . Thus [the man]4074-the man started to speak , and [he]4074-the man said : ' Without any doubt , [you]0-i must have been surprised by suddenly meeting [me]4074-the man in [this forest]1399-this forest when [you]0-i came here three days ago . [You]2354-you 95[4074-the man]

can not understand the type of person [I]0-i am , nor the nature of the conditions in which [I]0-i am , if [I]0-i do not tell [you]2354-you . [I]0-i , as [you]2354-you are looking at [me]0-i , am partly human and partly gnomish , why ? Because [[my]0-i father]548-my father was human , and [he]548-my father was [a hunter]574-a hunter too . The time that [I]0-i am now talking about is long , long time ago ; but [[my]0-i father]548-my father was [the oldest of [all the himters in [the world]639-the world]2359-all the himters in the world]2358-the oldest of all the himters in the world at ttie time when [I]0-i was bom . [[My]0-i mother]924-my mother was not [a human being]4257-a human being at all , [she]924-my mother was [a gnome]1208-a gnome . But [[my]0-i mother]924-my mother was very beautiful indeed . As it was the trait of [most beautiful women]2365-most beautiful women , [[my]0-i mother]924-my mother was very proud ; [the notably important gnomes who were interested in [her]924-my mother when [she]924-my mother was [a girl]1301-a girl]2367-the notably important gnomes who were interested in her when she was a girl didnot get a favourable reception from [her]924-my mother , until [those honourable ones]2369-those honourable ones left [her]924-my mother , and it became difficult for [her]924-my mother to find [a husband]1504-a husband . At long last , [[my]0-i father]548-my father found [her]924-my mother in [the - forest]2372-the - forest , and [he]548-my father married [her]924-my mother , as the story goes . [[My]0-i father]548-my father had heard about the fairy , and [he]548-my father began to look for [her]924-my mother arormd . In those days , [women]589-women were wiser than those ( [women ) of today]2375-women ) of today , because [they]589-women did not many [men]634-men just because of [their]589-women bluffing alone , [they]589-women did not marry [men]634-men just because of [their]589-women handsomeness alone , but [they]589-women married [men]634-men if [the men]2379-the men were [powerful men]2380-powerful men , if [they]2379-the men had a deep love that could not fade , if [they]2379-the men recognized what was . right as right , and . what was befitting as what was befitting ; for if [a person]1088-a person recognizes what is right as what is right , and what is befitting as what is befitting , [we]2382-we Would not find [the person]1393-the person doing something that does not befit [the son of man]699-the son of man . Therefore , at this time , [[my]0-i mother]924-my mother took [[my]0-i father]548-my father into the rocks of [[their]2387-their home]4189-their home , and [they]2387-their tested [him]548-my father . There , [[my]0-i father]548-my father fought a lion ; [he]548-my father killed a lion with an axe ; [[my]0-i father]548-my father fought with a leopard ; [[my]0-i father]548-my father fought a python , and killed the python with a whip , and [he]548-my father spent seven days without food . " When [[my]0-i father]548-my father completed this test , [tire woman]2393-tire woman then asked [him]548-my father , and.she said , ' Why do [you]548-my father love [me]2393-tire woman ? '[2393-tire woman] And [[my]0-i father]548-my father answered like [a wise man]4403-a wise man , and [he]548-my father said , ' [I]548-my father love [you]4442-the woman , but [I]548-my father do not understand the reason . myself;2 ^ 8 whenever [I]548-my father see [jlou]412-jlou , [I]548-my father simply love [you]412-jlou . '[548-my father] [The woman]4442-the woman answered ; and [she]4442-the woman said , ' [I]4442-the woman will marry [you]548-my father ; [[you]548-my father [wise man]5325-wise man]5324-you wise man , because the most complete love is the love for which one can not explain the reason ; if [a ptferson]5326-a ptferson loves [someone]4288-someone because of [his]5326-a ptferson brilliance,^ ! ® if [she]4442-the woman marries [him]5326-a ptferson because of [his]5326-a ptferson bluffing , if [she]4442-the woman marries [him]5326-a ptferson because of the words of [hid]4442-the woman mouth , if [she]4442-the woman marries [him]5326-a ptferson because of the way [he]5326-a ptferson walks , the love would not amount to anything . Because a day will come , when these tilings might be gone , or [you]5328-you might be tired of them ; but if [you]5328-you love [a person]1088-a person and [you]5328-you can not tell exactly why [you]5328-you love [him]1088-a person , [your]5328-you love is a complete love . Therefore , [I]4442-the woman will many [you]5328-you ; [you]5328-you are going to be [ttie fatixer of [[my]4442-the woman home]1164-my home]5330-ttie fatixer of my home . '^[4442-the woman] ® " [Ybu]413-ybu , [[my]0-i friend]4227-my friend , thus did [[my]0-i father]548-my father marry [[my]0-i mother]924-my mother , and by the time that [I]0-i was born , [[my]0-i mother]924-my mother , in as much as [she]924-my mother was [herself]924-my mother -4 fairy , [she]924-my mother gently sneaked to [the dome of [heaven]1120-heaven]1620-the dome of heaven , and [she]924-my mother plucked one of the fruits of tile tree of life , [she]924-my mother gave it to [me]0-i , and [I]0-i ate it , thus [Lcanhot]414-lcanhot die forever . Butvtiien God [the ( heavenly ) King]4559-the ( heavenly ) king learned of this , [he]4559-the ( heavenly ) king ordered 96

[the angels]2404-the angels to come and take [me]0-i after [I]0-i had lived among [the children of [men]634-men]633-the children of men for seventy years , and bring [me]0-i close to the gate of heaven . * . This was why [you]2407-you found [me]0-i here , where [I]0-i can hear the cock crowing from heaven . [I]0-i , [the only one Baba - Onirungbont - yeuke , who lives on [the hillock of [die rock]2410-die rock]2409-the hillock of die rock]2408-the only one baba - onirungbont - yeuke , who lives on the hillock of die rock . " ' Listen , let [me]2433-a man near our house tell [you]5346-you a short story : " '[2433-a man near our house] One day , when [I]0-i was among [the children of [men]634-men]633-the children of men , there was [a man near [[our]2425-we house]4204-our house]2433-a man near our house ; [die man]5305-die man was very poor , and [he]5305-die man had [a wife]4644-a wife . [This wife]2437-this wife loved [[her]2437-this wife husband]864-her husband very much . " ' At long last ; [one wealthy man]5347-one wealthy man decided to help [this poor man]5348-this poor man . [This wealthy man]5349-this wealthy man had a piece of land which was filled with palm bees . [He]5349-this wealthy man gave [tills poor man]5352-tills poor man some money which [he]5349-this wealthy man needed to buy some gourds and all wine tapping equipment . ' " [This man]959-this man found another means to get some money with which [he]959-this man bought other gourds , and [he]959-this man decided to watch and see what was breaking [his]959-this man gourds ; thus after [he]959-this man had tapped the wine , [he]959-this man did not go [home]569-home ; [he]959-this man climbed to the top of a tree , watching what would happen to [his]959-this man gourds . ' " When [this strange creature]5360-this strange creature came to those palm trees , [he]5360-this strange creature began to climb them one by by one , taking the wine on top of them ; after [he]5360-this strange creature had turned the wine from the gourd into the big gourd which [he]5360-this strange creature brought , [he]5360-this strange creature would throw the gourd to the ground , and the gourd would break . '[2475-a hen] " When , on a certain day , as [he]959-this man sat down in [[his]959-this man courtyard]2474-his courtyard playing in die evening , [he]959-this man heard [a hen]2475-a hen telling [[her]2475-a hen chicks]2476-her chicks to be careful and get out of [a certain place]2477-a certain place , because if [they]2476-her chicks stayed long tiiere spreading the dirt around there , it would not be long when [they]2476-her chicks would find a bag of gold coins at the bottom , and that [the owner of [die house]2479-die house]2478-the owner of die house might , by so doing , see it . '[4442-the woman] When it was in the night , one day , [this man]959-this man and [[his]959-this man elder wife]2498-his elder wife were in [the room]4637-the room ; [the wife]4633-the wife was outside ; as [they]2501-they were in [the room]4637-the room , [the man]4074-the man was hearing the rats , talking to [each other]925-each other ; [they]2501-they were scolding [the man]4074-the man saying that [he]4074-the man did not sleep on time , so that [they]2501-they would be free to go and eat . [A woman]850-a woman is a snail shell , afid [a husband]1504-a husband is die snail : wherever the snails goes , it goes with - die shell.237 Once marriage is started , trouble has started ; as [wives]1510-wives multiply , the love would continue to dwindle , and a host of [men]634-men are living with ( [[their]634-men bitter ) enemies]5462-their bitter ) enemies , whom [they]634-men call [women]589-women . Act according to [your]5464-you capacity , [you]5464-you , [my]0-i friend;238 that [[your]5464-you wife]4479-your wife loves [you]5464-you before [she]4479-your wife enters [[your]5464-you house]1298-your house . " By die same token , there are [many envious people in [this [our]5472-our world]5471-this our world]5470-many envious people in this our world , and there is no way in which [they]5470-many envious people in this our world can not show [their]5470-many envious people in this our world envy . " Thus did [Baba - Onirungbon]398-baba - onirungbon speak [his]398-baba - onirungbon words , and when [he]398-baba - onirungbon finished those words , [I]0-i answered , and [I]0-i said , '[0-i] [[My]0-i dear friend]5134-my dear friend , is that the end of [your]5134-my dear friend speech ? " After tjiis , [Baba - Onirungbon]398-baba - onirungbon got up from where [he]398-baba - onirungbon sat , and [he]398-baba - onirungbon 101

pointed to a tree that had very beautiful flowers , [he]398-baba - onirungbon said , ' Look at that tree over there , the tree whose leaves are deeply green over there . After that , look at the right hand side near the tree , [you]5134-my dear friend will see another tr^ which is a little smaller ; [you]5134-my dear friend will see that bofli of [them]5479-them resemble each other . [The older of the two]5484-the older of the two was [a boy]5485-a boy , [the second one]5112-the second one was [a girl]1301-a girl . " In the Olden days , when [the world]639-the world was not like this , when [the children of [men]634-men]633-the children of men knew die value of [God^^s]421-god^^s more than now , [God]341-god always sent a messenger from [‘ heaven]5579-‘ heaven to come and visit [the world]639-the world ; [die messenger]5581-die messenger used to come every seven years ; [die messenger]5581-die messenger was [one of the creatures in [heaven]1120-heaven]5583-one of the creatures in heaven ; [the people in [the world]639-the world]5278-the people in the world used to call [him]5581-die messenger [the Representative of [God]341-god]5587-the representative of god . had . a root in [the world]639-the world ; [he]2596-he used to be a special creature in [heaven]1120-heaven . '[5305-die man] " It happened once upon a time ; [a king]4355-a king sent [[his]4355-a king wife]628-his wife to go and cook a soup for [him]4355-a king . It was not long after that that [the wife]4633-the wife brought three fresh fishes before [this king]4716-this king — one was black ; one was red ; one was white . The one that was black was very black indeed ; the one that was red was very red indeed ; the one that was white was very white indeed . These fishes were a surprise to [the king]760-the king ; thus [he]760-the king ordered [[his]760-the king wife]628-his wife to go and cook them for [him]760-the king , and [she]628-his wife went . ' " It was not long after this , when [she]4633-the wife came back before [the king]760-the king , panting , and [she]4633-the wife began to speak ; [she]4633-the wife said , '[628-his wife] [[Your]760-the king Highness]4709-your highness , [I]0-i saw something terrible today . which [I]0-i was cooking the food suddenly split into two , and 1 saw [a girl with a sword in ( [her]2910-a girl with a sword in ( her ) hand who threw off my fish on the fire ) hand who threw off [my]0-i fish on the fire]2910-a girl with a sword in ( her ) hand who threw off my fish on the fire . ' " When [the woman]4442-the woman finished Ker talk , [the king]760-the king got up , and [he]760-the king said , '[760-the king] Go on and show [me]0-i the fishes , ' and both of [them]5730-them were going together . '[760-the king] " In a short while , [this fisherman]2911-this fisherman brought three fishes like the first time , and [the king]760-the king followed [[his]760-the king wife]628-his wife to [the house of food]2914-the house of food ; when [he]760-the king got [there]642-there , [he]760-the king said that [[his]760-the king wife]628-his wife should start cooking the soup in [his]760-the king presence . [The king]760-the king fell down , and [the king]760-the king 's crown flew forward , [the king]760-the king fainted ; [the wife]4633-the wife fainted ; [the messenger who followed [the king]760-the king]2927-the messenger who followed the king fainted ; it was when the wind blew over [them]2929-they that [they]2929-they woke up . " ' When [the king]760-the king got up and went into [the palace]1597-the palace and was rested , [he]760-the king sent for [this fisherman]2911-this fisherman , and [he]760-the king told [him]2911-this fisherman to catch three fish like those again . " Before [the mah]5739-the mah brought the fish which [the king]760-the king sent fc5r , [the king]760-the king had sent for [[his]760-the king chiefs]5742-his chiefs saying th at . [they]5742-his chiefs should come to [[his]760-the king palace]5743-his palace . '[760-the king] " After this , [the king]760-the king asked [this man]959-this man where [[his]760-the king wife]628-his wife , [a witch]1359-a witch was , and [he]760-the king answered [him]959-this man thus , saying , ' [[My]760-the king friend]4227-my friend , [I]760-the king do not know exactly where [she]628-his wife is , but what [I]760-the king see is that since [she]628-his wife had turned [me]760-the king to the way [you]760-the king now meet [me]760-the king , [she]628-his wife had turned [the city]1277-the city over which [I]760-the king was [a king]4355-a king to [a stagnant river]5759-a stagnant river which [you]760-the king see over there witti [her]628-his wife witchcraft . [Agutan - iriid]433-agutan - inaki was [a spoilt person]5984-a spoilt person : [he]433-agutan - inaki was [one of those who never knew when [people]917-people were making fun of [them]917-people]5985-one of those who never knew when people were making fun of them ; when [they]3127-they put on a buba^^^ and [you]3128-you began to flatter [them]3127-they 124[3127-they]

saying that [they]3127-they were wearing dandogc^^^ made out of sanyai?'^'^ material , [they]3127-they would be pleased with [you]3128-you ; when [they]3127-they put on the clothes which do not fit [them]3127-they , and [you]3128-you said that [their]3127-they clothes were better than that of [a king]4355-a king , [they]3127-they would be pleased with [you]3128-you ; when [they]3127-they spoke at a meeting , [they]3127-they would be asking continuously ; ' Do n't [you]3128-you see that [my]3127-they speech was better than that of die rest ( of [the people]654-the people ) ? The reason was that [nobody]950-nobody should look at the water , because [he]4074-the man who looks at it would be looking at the throne of [[God]341-god [the Master of glory]3192-the master of glory and die powerful in - spirits who were standing around the throne of [God]341-god]3191-god the master of glory and die powerful in - spirits who were standing around the throne of god and were praising [Him]4074-the man who made [them]3191-god the master of glory and die powerful in - spirits who were standing around the throne of god , who made [others]556-others , who made [all of [us]3180-us]4734-all of us . ' '[398-baba - onirungbon] [Baba - Onirungbon - yeuke]398-baba - onirungbon told [us]3180-us diat the water in the bottle which hegave to [us]3180-us was a strange water , and that there was nothing [we]3180-us could . not do with it : if [we]3180-us poured it on shrub and [we]3180-us told the shrub to change ' to [a human being]4257-a human being [it]6072-it would become [a human being]4257-a human being ; if [we]3180-us said that [it]6072-it • should change into an animal , [it]6072-it would become an animal , because • the authority of [God]341-god was on [its]6072-it body . " This fight was so much : it surpassed what mouth could describe , but at last , [we]3414-we were grateful to [God]341-god [the ( heavenly ) King]4559-the ( heavenly ) king that [we]3414-we were [the victorious ones]6146-the victorious ones . [He]3448-he whom [Ojola - ibinu]283-olowo - aiye disparages , whom [the rest of the creation]3449-the rest of the creation are glorifying , that today that [I]0-i am in trouble let this sand change and become poisonous ants , and let [them]3450-they begin to bite these snakes .^57 After [he]0-i had said this , the sand truly changed and became ants , and [they]3450-they started biting those snakes . As the ants were biting the snakes , the snakes wanted to bit [them]3450-they , too , and whenever [they]3450-they did that , [they]3450-they were biting [themselves]3450-they . By so doing every one of those snakes began to kill [one another]1063-one another ; [their]3450-they very own poison gripped [them]3450-they . By doing so , [they]3450-they killed [one another]1063-one another completely ' ; thus did [we]3446-we do and [we]3446-we were victorious over [them]3450-they . After [we]3446-we had done this , [we]3446-we went back 138[3450-they]

to enter into ' [the palace]1597-the palace ; [we]3446-we brought food out , and [we]3446-we began to eat . . In the beginning , at the very inception of [the universe]4086-the universe , when [Satan]353-satan fell in [heaven]1120-heaven , and [God]341-god put a line of demarcation rtiid - way between [good heaven^^^ bad heaven]3469-good heaven^^^ bad heaven , there was a tree at the edge of [the chasm]3470-the chasm without a bottom which was a demarcator between [good heaven and bad heaven]3471-good heaven and bad heaven . around the worldBut [a sinner]729-a sinner will not go unpunished , except if [the sinner]3486-the sinner repents . Notes 1 [The world]639-the world ['s rich man]3684-'s rich man . 2 . koko - eliibg is an associative construction ( the pot of yam flower eliibg is flour obtained from the kind of yams botanically known as dioscurea rotunda . 3 . Palm oil is obtained from palm fruit found mostly irt [file southern part of [Nigeria]11-nigeria]3685-file southern part of nigeria . [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa likens [the dusty road]3686-the dusty road to the palm oil here . However , the rusty brown colour would have been more appropriate to describe [the dirt road that [he]187-fagunwa is tadking about in this narrative]3687-the dirt road that he is tadking about in this narrative , but [I]0-i have kept [his]187-fagunwa simile in order to preserve the flow of [his]187-fagunwa style and thought as much as possible . 4 . Sparrow - like - bird , but little bigger than sparrow ; it is red featheredand is found mostly in [the western part of [Africa]19-africa]3688-the western part of africa . 5 . This is certainly a hyperbolic expression . [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa sometimes does that to achieve parallelism in this case , between " cry " and " speaking " . 6 . This part of the narrative is autobiographical . Resell ( Recheal ) [Osunyomi]233-rachael osunyomi was the name of [[t).O. Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's mother]3689-t).o. fagunwa 's mother . See Ayo Bamgbose , 77je Novels of [D.O. Fagunwa]187-fagunwa ( [Benin City]23-benin city : [Ethiope Publishing Corporation]132-ethiope publishing corporation , 7 . The word translated " crossroads " here is orfta , which is " T " intersection . Literally , it is a spot where [three roads or paths]3690-three roads or paths intersect . [Y oruba people]3691-y oruba people believe tjiat orfta is [the meeting spot of]3692-the meeting spot of [the spirits and ghosts]3693-the spirits and ghosts . Sacrifices are being taken [there]642-there either to invoke a good spirit for certain help needed , such as prayer for the gift of [a child]4510-a child , weaSh , etc . , or the bad spirit appeased in case of illness , or some diseases associated with the power of the vicious spirit . Therefore , for one to lake [his]187-fagunwa sacrifice beyond orfta is to go out qf [one]187-fagunwa 's expected boundary , hence here a grievous mistake . The idea is thus proverbially employed hwe . 8 . elubg , yam - flour , like mashed potato , is normally prepared with boiling water . This metaphor simply portrays the complexity yf [the narrator]4122-the narrator 's dilemma here . It means that everything is di^ointed and out of place : a complete disorder withinhis psyche as reflected around hiih . 9 . g^rd is a substance like cream of wheat , obtained from cassava , which is a type of tuber mostly found in [Nigeria]11-nigeria and [most parts of [West Africa]133-west africa]3697-most parts of west africa . 10 . This is a reference to [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's first volume entitled dgbdju Odenfnd Igbo Irunmgle , translated by [Soyinka]200-wole soyinka as [The Forest of [A Thousand Demons]3698-a thousand demons]134-the forest of a thousand demons : [A Hunter]574-a hunter 's Saga , published by Nelson , [London]14-london , in 1968 . 11 . [The forest]4092-the forest that is referred to here is the setting of file first novel mentioned in note No . 10 . [It]4092-the forest is inhabited by ghosts and all kinds of spirits . This is a way of . tying [his]187-fagunwa second sequel ( [The Forest of [God]186-god]186-god ) to tire first novel . 12 . [Orfki]477-orfki is an attributive family name . It is not what [we]3701-we can call a nickname — in [Yoruba]12-yoruba — it goes deeper , than fltat . It has a very strong rhetorical important . As a matter of fact , it constitutes a greater part of Yoruba poetiy known as ijdld , [Ewi]3702-ewi or [Rira]478-rira , or a prosaic history of [a family]3703-a family 's heroic deeds . This , in classical rhetoric , is tmownas epideictic 148

Edxvard P.J. Corbett , C / ass / ca / yZh^fohc ' 5&c / ent ( Second edn . ako R.C. [I]283-olowo - aiye prefer the literal translation " child of [the world]639-the world " in order to be in tune with [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's narrative style here . In other words , ftie emotional depth of the subjunctive mood here is preserved by giving it such a literid tarnation . Ajgdiran ( aje - dwran ) literally means witch - becomes - generation . Idiomatically expressed , one would say witchcraft runs - in - [the - family]6328-the - family . It is a comihon thing in most African cultures to think that [someone]4288-someone is responsible for [the other person]6330-the other person 's death through tire use of witchcraft ; So , [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa is being both realistic as well as satiric here . Qmg . araiye literally means [the children of [the world]639-the world]767-the children of the world , but is both semantically and communicatively acceptable to render it as " [the people]654-the people . " In Yoruba culture , as it is probably true of most African cultures , [a woman]850-a woman does not propose to [a man]852-a man . It quenches thirst as well as fills the stomach . For a younger learning a trade on the basis of indentuite , this could be a luxury . So it could be out of [his]3792-his reach financially at times . In Nigerian systems , when [someone]4288-someone is learning a trade , [he]4288-someone is almost like [a servant to [the master who teaches that trade]3805-the master who teaches that trade]3804-a servant to the master who teaches that trade . Spinach - like herb used for food . 115 . jR^<^is a special drum , which is like a bongo about 1 metre long , ' with 154[3813-god of iron , and masquerade ) festivals]

the top narrower than the base ; it is usually used for S^g6 and egungun ( [god of iron , and masquerade ) festivals]3813-god of iron , and masquerade ) festivals . 116 . is made of large gourd with cowries woven around it — a musical mstrument . 117 . A musical instrument made of a plywood box ( about 12 " x 18 " x 3 " ) . A hole is cut on the top cover like a guitar box , except that instead of strings across the hold like a guitar , pieces of metal - belt are used . The metal belts are graduated in tone to produce varieties of tones . It is used in juju music as well as ipMk , a Yoruba traditional music . Note also that the word jiyu here is not a medicine , but a name given to that kind of music because of the way it sounds when it is played . 118 . dsanyin is a kind of gSBirffir . In traditional African religion , it is conceived as having psychic power . Thus [its]3814-its spirit is invoked through [a little god in the comer of [[medicine man]3816-medicine man 's room]3817-medicine man 's room]3815-a little god in the comer of medicine man 's room , to foretell the future , and solve any mythical and domestic problems . It is invoked through ventroliqual trick . 119 . - ^ola - ibmu literally means " the python of fury . " 120 . A tiny gourd of medicine . 121 . See Note No . 8 on yam . 124 . is a handwoven fabric which is very expensive and is used on special occasions and festivals like marriages , naming ceremonies and festivals like Christmas and other Moslem festivals . 125 . [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's extended metaphor here serves to intensify the idea that the thing has done good things to the one who both appreciates and , deserves ( by the virtue of [his]187-fagunwa personality ) such a gesture . 126 . Ipo literally means place ; metaphorically , however , it means '[1718-the adult] horjour " or " respect " as used here . 127 . This is the basic ideal in Yoruba culture : [the young one]3818-the young one should listen to [the adult]1718-the adult , and must , as much as possible , not disregard [his]3820-his / [her]3821-her injunction or suggestion . It is assumed that [the grown - ups]3822-the grown - ups , having been in [the world]639-the world much longer than [the young ones]3824-the young ones , have been schooled by life , and have attained a level of wisdom ( through varied experiences in life ) , which elevates [them]3822-the grown - ups beyond the level of [the young ones]3824-the young ones . Thus , in [Yoruba]12-yoruba and mostly in African philosophy , life is a school : the longer [you]3795-you live , the better and the wiser [you]3795-you become . Thus , [an elderly person]3826-an elderly person has been to the school of life , and has graduated ; thus life in general has invested an authority in [him]3826-an elderly person : [he]3826-an elderly person is therefore qualified to guide [the young ones]3824-the young ones . 128 . It 's found to be delicious . 129 . " [[My]0-i darling]3828-my darling . " 130 . This is [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's allegorical pattern : the animals in [[his]187-fagunwa world]3829-his world are personified . 155

131 . Q16)g oni , " meaning [the owner of this day]4852-the owner of this day , " is another phrase - name for [God]186-god . In Yoruba culture , it is believed that [[one]4131-one 's in - laws]6354-one 's in - laws are like [a lion who should not be ill - treated or taken lightly]6355-a lion who should not be ill - treated or taken lightly . Instead , [they]6354-one 's in - laws should be respected and loved whole - heartedly . Thus , anything that would tarnish [one]4131-one 's image before [them]6354-one 's in - laws shouldbe eschewed . This relationship , of - course , is reciprocative between [the son - in - law]6357-the son - in - law and [the parents - in - law]6358-the parents - in - law . This kind of relationship also includes [all the members of [the immediate and distant family of the wife]6360-the immediate and distant family of the wife]6359-all the members of the immediate and distant family of the wife too . 161 . Here again , as usual , [we]6361-we see a heavy - handed didacticism in [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's narrative . The tone here is that of [an educator who seeks to instruct [[his]187-fagunwa students]6363-his students on the ideals of family life in terms of the responsibilities on the parts of [both [parents]6365-parents and [children]4102-children]6364-both parents and children]6362-an educator who seeks to instruct his students on the ideals of family life in terms of the responsibilities on the parts of both parents and children . 162 . [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's Judeo - Christian concept of life after death is in consonance with [his]187-fagunwa Yoruba belief that there is life on the other side after death . This is strongly supported by African Traditional Religion as well . 163 . This is one of the most important aspects of Yoruba culture in particular , and an African custom in general : when [a child]4510-a child is grown and becomes [a man]852-a man or [woman]1343-woman , [he]4510-a child is obliged to take very good care of [[his]4510-a child parents]616-his parents in terms of [housing]6372-housing , clothing and food . [[Our]6373-our elderly ones]6374-our elderly ones remain with [[their]6374-our elderly ones children]6375-their children , not in [the " home for [the elderly "]6377-the elderly "]6376-the " home for the elderly " , [they]6374-our elderly ones always enjoy the company of [the'ir children]6378-the'ir children and [grandchildren]6379-grandchildren . In Yoruba culture , when [an elderly person]3826-an elderly person dies , after the burial , [the immediate]3852-the immediate and [the extended family]3853-the extended family come together to have a big ceremony in which [they]3852-the immediate provide food of aU kinds as well as music of all sorts . It is usually an occasion for celebration , because [the deceased]3854-the deceased hadlivedtoaripe age , and had immortalised [himself]3854-the deceased thrdu^posterity . It is a thing of joy . " 211 . [Sari]500-sari is a term used ior the food which [Moslems]6404-moslems eat between 1 a.m. and 4 a.m. during the month of Ramadan , the month of fasting . Literally , " since the day [we]3893-we have been courting [each ofiier]3894-each ofiier . " 245 . A proverb which means that [both lovers]3895-both lovers are meant for [each other]925-each other . Thus whenever [one]4131-one goes [the other one]5403-the other one definitely follows . 246 . Euphemistic expression for death . 247 . The imagery here parallels the process of making mashed potatoes : when the water is boiling , a handful of mashed potatoes is put in ; without stirring it very well , the water boils and rises and covers the 161

handful of mashed potatoes . That is exactly what [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa thinks love does to [lovers]5185-lovers . 248 . [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's didacticism in terms of the caution and carefulness within the direction of [Cod]422-cod in the choice of [partners in marriage]3900-partners in marriage emanates from the Yoruba culture . Marriage in that culture , as is true in mOst ' African cultures , is one of the most serious things that [a man]852-a man and [a woman]850-a woman undertake in life . Thus a lot of time is spent in the probing of [the family]6343-the family from which [a young girl]6427-a young girl and [a young man]6428-a young man choose to marry . [They]3895-both lovers are very much concerned about compatibility on all levels of existence before the marriage could be done . Thus divorce is very rare . 249 . This is a Yoruba thought pattern in particular and Grat of [the Africans]4098-the africans in general concerning the concept of gerontology . [The Yoruba people]652-the yoruba people believe that the older [a man]852-a man gets in [the world]639-the world , the deeper and wider is [his]852-a man wisdom and experience ; hence [the elderly people]1407-the elderly people are indispensable both within [the family]6343-the family and within [the society as a whole]6435-the society as a whole . Thus the idea of [die home for [die elderly]6437-die elderly]6436-die home for die elderly is not appealing to [the Yoruba people]652-the yoruba people ; [they]652-the yoruba people want [[their]652-the yoruba people elderly ones]6439-their elderly ones to be with [them]652-the yoruba people and enjoy the rest of [their]652-the yoruba people days with [children]4102-children and [grandchildren]6379-grandchildren , etc . That , to [them]652-the yoruba people , is the joy of old age . 250 . Here again is anodier aspect of [Yoruba]12-yoruba culture which gives a lot of respect ( sometimes to the extent of fear ) to [the elderly people]1407-the elderly people , from whom [the young ones]3824-the young ones are supposed to learn things about life . 251 . In other words , " ... [he]852-a man isJooking for trouble . " 252 . That is , [the adult through the experiences and wisdom wrought by age]6444-the adult through the experiences and wisdom wrought by age , knows the deeper things of life than [the young people]6445-the young people . 253 . Here again , according to the mores of [the Africans]4098-the africans in general , and that of [the Yoruba people]652-the yoruba people in particular , wisdom , on the part of ) [[he]852-a man [young people]6449-young people]6448-he young people , lies in [his]852-a man recognition of [the adult]1718-the adult 's place in [die world]1548-die world , and [his]852-a man willingness to acknowledge it . 254 . [i.e.]6452-i.e. , [people]917-people 's ambition in life should be moderate in order to avoid an undue anxiety . 255 . This is a title for [diose who are making , or have made pilgrimage]6454-diose who are making , or have made pilgrimage to [Mecca]143-mecca . 256 . [Imam]504-imam is [a Moslerr^priest]6455-a moslerr^priest . 257 . [The Moslem spiritual leader]6456-the moslem spiritual leader is called [Anal)?Muhammed]505-anal)?muhammed . [Anabi]472-the moslem remefijbers anabi means [a messenger or angel]6457-a messenger or angel . In other words , " When [the children of [men]634-men]633-the children of men honoured [God]186-god . " 259 . [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa is apparently Miltonic here : [he]187-fagunwa describes the hurling of [Satan]353-satan out of [heaven]1120-heaven as found also in [Milton]238-milton 's Paradise Lostl , 36 - 74 ; see also Isaiah 14:12 ; [Jude]507-jude , 1:6 . [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's Judeo - Christian theme constitutes a ■ single thread that runs through [his]187-fagunwa narratives . [He]187-fagunwa consistently portrays [God]186-god 's sovereignty over [the heaven]2109-the heaven as well as the affairs of [men]634-men in [the world]639-the world . [Man]590-man 's duty therefore , is to obey [him]590-man and do [his]590-man will . This is the only Way out of die grip of [Satan]353-satan who has been hurled out of [heaven]1120-heaven only to disorganise and deceive [God]186-god 's creation here in [the world]639-the world . 260 . That means'that [the people]654-the people cast speU on [his]187-fagunwa life , and things begin to fall apart . This is an explanation to human sufferings : most of the time , [other people]1454-other people 's catastrophy and downs of life are blamed on witches and [wizards]4212-wizards . . 272 . The pronoun nwon third person plural " [they]654-the people " is not grammatically consistent with tine subject of the sentence . Thus the use of " [they]654-the people " would make it ambiguous . Hence , [my]187-fagunwa choice of " [he]508-babaldwo " for third person singular . 273 . This is an aspect of [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's concept of theodicy : [he]187-fagunwa attempts to justify the goodness of [God]186-god in spite of the existence of evil , which manifests itself in various modes , such as sickness , suffering of all kinds , catastrophies , etc . in [the world]639-the world . This is a sign of healthy personality in African culture , and more so , in Yoruba culture in particular . 277 . Or health . 278 . In the African culture , the training of [a child]4510-a child is not confined to [the parents]1990-the parents alone ; it extends to ^11 [the relatives]3350-the relatives , even to [the community]3907-the community as well . Thus the training of [a cjuld]3908-a cjuld is a communal effort as well . 285 . [I]4122-the narrator have here translated the Yoruba word pele with a sentence instead of a single word , because the context calls for such situation in which [the speaker]6491-the speaker normally sympathises with [the character]868-the character . Kneeling down [whena woman]3918-whena woman is [greetingher husband]3919-greetingher husband , settinghis food before [him]3919-greetingher husband , or handling almost anything to [him]3919-greetingher husband , is a sign of respect that is expected from [a woman]850-a woman — this is part of Yoruba culture . 291 . Igi is a wood used to roof [a house]5345-a house . It is signiffcant in the short incantation because of the symbol : it symbolises stillness and muteness , the position and the condition in which [the woman]4442-the woman wants [[her]4442-the woman husband]864-her husband to be while [she]4442-the woman is away taking care of [her]4442-the woman lustful business . This is an element of what [I]0-i like to term the truth of fiction which permeates the novels of [D.O. Fagunwa]187-fagunwa . What [I]0-i mean by the truth of fiction is this : though the story as told by [this character]3865-this character is not true it is probable ; such a thing is not uncommon within the cultural experience of [the Africans]502-the africans or occultists all over [the world]639-the world . 292 . The idea of kissing as a romantic element here is foreign to African culture . [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa obviously picked it up while [he]187-fagunwa was in [England]144-england . This is a part of Yoruba culture : when [an elderly person]3826-an elderly person dies , [[his]3826-an elderly person children]1693-his children celebrate [his]3826-an elderly person death and burial by putting up a big party , depending on the social status of [flxe children]3944-flxe children and that of [the deceased]3854-the deceased . Even if [he]3826-an elderly person did not have [any children]3946-any children , [[his]3826-an elderly person nephews]3947-his nephews or [relatives]4503-relatives are expected to do what [[his]3826-an elderly person children]1693-his children woxild have done for [him]3826-an elderly person at [his]3826-an elderly person death ; if [the deceased]3854-the deceased was very old before [his]3854-the deceased death , and had [many children]3951-many children and [grandchildren]6379-grandchildren , [his]3953-his / [her]3954-her death is celebrated with great pomp and jubilation,'thanking [God]186-god for [the deceased]3854-the deceased 's life , and for the lives of [the children]1573-the children , [grandchildren]6379-grandchildren and [the great , grandchildren]3958-the great , grandchildren , as the case may be . 307 . [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's verbal gymnastics is seen in this metaphorical hyperbole ; " laughter weds lau^ter " is [his]187-fagunwa way of saying that ’[4029-i.e] ' [we]6495-we were so happy when [we]6495-we met , [we]6495-we were talking and [we]6495-we were laughing so hard ... " 380 . Literally , " [they]6496-they would be looking at [others]556-others with little eyes . " 381 . [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa tries to give [the reader]871-the reader a hint about the structure of [his]187-fagunwa narrative . It is very complex ; the story is told from the first person point of view , except that it is being reported through [the third person]1287-the third person . The dominating point of view of the story , however , is [the first person]6500-the first person . This is what is known as oblique narrative . 382 . [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa gives [us]6495-we [his]187-fagunwa rationale for file story ; [he]187-fagunwa releases [his]187-fagunwa intent for [his]187-fagunwa literary undertaking . This shows that didacticism is not accidental a residue of [his]187-fagunwa naivete in [his]187-fagunwa works , but an accomplishment of a purpose . [His]187-fagunwa basic purpose is to teach — to teach delightfully fiirough the verbal gymnastics and dazzling rhetoric — a vehicle which conveys [the reader]871-the reader so smoothly that [he]187-fagunwa forgets the pain of the bumpy road of " sermons " and proverbs that are intended to teach morals . Thus in spite of [the modem reader]6502-the modem reader 's resentment , [he]187-fagunwa is lured to read along by [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's rhetorical prowess . 383 . Notice [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's theological diction here as well as [his]187-fagunwa consistent Biblical language throughout the narrative . [Fagunwa]187-fagunwa 's Judeo - Christian concept and beliefs filter through [his]187-fagunwa works of art . As amatter of fact , the art to [him]187-fagunwa , is simply a means to an end , not an end itself . True art is meant to pleasingly teach , a notion which had been a part of the philosophy of literary art for centuries . See Wilbur Scott/,Fz've Approaches of Literary Criticism ! An Arrangement of Contemporaiy E^ys ( [New York]65-new york : [Collier Books]149-collier books , 1962 ) , pp . -41 . 384 . In other words , '[4038-he] [he]4038-he disappeared . " 385 . [The elderly peojfle]4039-the elderly peojfle have accummulated fiie wisdom from [other people]1454-other people in [their]4039-the elderly peojfle experiences in life , to the extent that [they]4039-the elderly peojfle themsdves have become wise ; thus are [no fools]4041-no fools . 386 . See .Matthew 5:37 for this biblical allusion . 387 . [i.e.]4042-i.e. , " daily bread . " 388 . This term , ' is simply an idiophonic expression . There is no such bird in existence , for all [we]6503-we know . This convinces [the reader]871-the reader - fiiat '[242-nelson] this epilogue is basically for [file school children]4043-file school children . ' It sounds like the end - of - the - term sermonette . 389 . This prayer is for the polygamous family , where there is always bitter rivaliy between two wives,-or among [many wives of [the same husband]6506-the same husband]6505-many wives of the same husband . 169[242-nelson]

< 6 [Forest of God]186-god is [Gabriel Ajadi]188-gabriel ajadi ’s English translation of th6 Voruba classic novel , Igbo Olodiimare , written by [D.O. Fagunwa]187-fagunwa . [Olowoaiye]470-olowoaiye sets out on [his]470-olowoaiye epic journey tQ [the Forest of God]186-god , to prove [hims'elf]470-olowoaiye as [a powerful hunter , who wants to become deeper in wisdom , and greater m power]4056-a powerful hunter , who wants to become deeper in wisdom , and greater m power . [He]470-olowoaiye there confronts gnomes , and several weird and supernatural creatures . Survival is [his]470-olowoaiye only choice , and that depends on how supematurally powerful and how wise , [he]470-olowoaiye too is . [Gabriel Ajadi]188-gabriel ajadi ’s powerful English translation o this allegorical novel is unique- the conventional theories of translation are carefully blended , the'style is that of [a very competent * and resilient user of the English language]4057-a very competent * and resilient user of the english language , and the Introduction Annotation and relevant Bibliography supplied by [the translator]579-the translator , ensuce that [readers]4059-readers , whether with or without the traditiona ' and lingua bacl^round of [the original author]4060-the original author , [D.O.
